project_title: Community Health and Air Quality Implications of Refinery Retrofits and Retirements
project_description:
DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT WILL LEVERAGE THE NATURAL EXPERIMENT AFFORDED BY A RECENT OIL REFINERY CLOSURE IN NORTHERN CA, STATE-OF-THE-SCIENCE AIR QUALITY MODELING, AND A UNIQUE DATASET OF AMBIENT AIR POLLUTION MONITORING DATA TO QUANTIFY THE IMPACTS OF REFINERY EMISSIONS ON LOCAL AIR QUALITY AND COMMUNITY HEALTH AND COMPARE PRESENT CONDITIONS TO ALTERNATE SCENARIOS OF REFINERY RETIREMENT AND BIOFUEL CONVERSION.ACTIVITIES:SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT WILL: 1) UTILIZE THE 2020 CLOSURE OF THE MARATHON OIL REFINERY IN MARTINEZ, CALIFORNIA AS A NATURAL EXPERIMENT TO QUANTIFY THE IMPACTS OF OIL REFINING ON RATES OF PRETERM BIRTH, EMERGENCY ROOM VISITS, AND HOSPITALIZATIONS; 2) MODEL THE AIR QUALITY, HEALTH, AND ECONOMIC IMPACTS OF RETIRING THE FOUR OPERATIONAL OIL REFINERIES IN THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA AND COMPARE THEM TO ALTERNATIVE SCENARIOS OF RETROFIT TO BIOFUEL PRODUCTION; AND 3) ENGAGE COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND ADVOCATES IN STUDY DESIGN AND RESULTS DISSEMINATION AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF A WEB-BASED INTERACTIVE TOOL TO INFORM PETROLEUM REFINERY CONVERSION OR RETIREMENT.SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARDEE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA BERKELEY WILL BE INVOLVED IN THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE STUDY DESIGN AS WELL AS IN THE DATA ANALYSIS, INTERPRETATION AND DISSEMINATION OF STUDY RESULTS. THE REQUESTED AMOUNT IS $196,558.

SUBAWARDEE PSE ENERGY WILL BE INVOLVED IN AIR QUALITY MODELING, HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT, AND DEVELOPMENT OF AN ONLINE REFINERY RETIREMENT AND RETROFIT DATA VISUALIZATION TOOL. THE REQUESTED AMOUNT IS $390,000.

SUBAWARDEE ASIAN PACIFIC ENVIRONMENTAL NETWORK WILL SUPPORT THE PROJECT BY PROVIDING ADVICE TO THE STUDY TEAM, ASSISTING IN RESULTS TRANSLATION AND DISSEMINATION, AND PARTICIPATING IN AND COORDINATING REGULAR COMMUNITY ADVISORY COMMITTEE MEETINGS. THE REQUESTED AMOUNT IS $200,440.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS. OTHER EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS DOCUMENTING RESEARCH FINDINGS ON LINK BETWEEN HEALTH AND AIR QUALITY IMPACTS OF OIL REFINERY OPERATIONS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF THE AGGREGATE AIR QUALITY AND HEALTH BENEFITS OF RETIRING OR RETROFITTING MULTIPLE PETROLEUM REFINERIES IN A DISPROPORTIONATELY IMPACTED REGION. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE RESIDENTS LIVING NEAR OIL REFINERIES IN THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA AS WELL AS RESEARCHERS WORKING WITH SIMILAR COMMUNITIES TO ADDRESS AIR QUALITY DEGRADATION AND PUBLIC HEALTH CONCERNS ASSOCIATED WITH OIL REFINING FOR ENERGY PRODUCTION.

project_title: Drivers of Energy Service Transitions and Impacts on Well-Being in Forest Dependent Rural Communities
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL IS TO ANALYZE IMPACTS OF CURRENT ENERGY SYSTEMS AND PATHWAYS FOR ENERGY TRANSITIONS THAT ENHANCE WELL-BEING THROUGH IMPROVED PUBLIC HEALTH, ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY, AND ENERGY JUSTICE OUTCOMES WITH A FOCUS ON UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, INCLUDING A TRIBAL NATION AND RURAL COMMUNITIES, IN A FOREST-DEPENDENT REGION IN NORTHERN MICHIGAN.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL: 1) QUANTIFY THE IMPACTS OF WOOD, PAPER, PLASTICS, AND TIRE-DERIVED FUELS (WPPT) ENERGY GENERATION IN TERMS OF ECONOMIC WELL-BEING AT THE HOUSEHOLD AND COMMUNITY SCALE AND OF AIR QUALITY AFFECTING HUMAN HEALTH; 2) EVALUATE THE IMPACTS AND POTENTIAL TRANSITION DRIVERS ASSOCIATED WITH LOCAL USE OF FUELWOOD ALONG WITH IMPROVED VENTILATION AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY OPTIONS; AND 3) ASSESS THE POTENTIAL DECARBONIZATION OF THE ELECTRIC POWER SECTOR TO PROVIDE ECONOMIC BENEFITS AND SECURE ACCESS TO ENERGY SERVICES IN WAYS THAT ENHANCE THE MANUFACTURING SECTOR AS WELL AS COMMUNITY AND HOUSEHOLD WELL-BEING IN TERMS OF AIR QUALITY, PUBLIC HEALTH AND ENERGY JUSTICE.SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARDEE CENTER FOR ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO PROTOCOL DEVELOPMENT IN ALL ASPECTS OF INDOOR AIR QUALITY RESEARCH AND RESIDENTIAL ENERGY AUDIT AND ENERGY ASSESSMENTS. ($135,000)OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS. OTHER EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE REPORTS AND JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS DOCUMENTING RESULTS OF THE RESEARCH. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF: 1) THE AIR QUALITY IMPACTS OF WPPT ENERGY PRODUCTION FOR UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES; 2) IMPACTS OF CURRENT ENERGY SERVICES PROVISION ON INDOOR AIR QUALITY AND POTENTIAL DRIVERS TO INCREASE ENERGY EFFICIENCY AND USE OF WOOD PRODUCTS IN WAYS THAT DO NOT HAVE NEGATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH IMPACTS; AND 3) POTENTIAL DRIVERS OF A TRANSITION IN FOREST PRODUCT USE THAT CAN SUPPORT JUST ENERGY SERVICES ACCESS AS WELL AS ECONOMIC WELL-BEING FOR HOUSEHOLDS, COMMUNITIES, AND INDUSTRIES THAT ENHANCE EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE RURAL COMMUNITIES AND TRIBAL NATIONS IN FOREST DEPENDENT AREAS IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION AS RESEARCHERS WORKING WITH SIMILAR COMMUNITIES TO ADDRESS ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS ASSOCIATED WITH LARGE-SCALE CHANGES IN THE ENERGY SYSTEMS.

project_title: Renewable Energy, Environmental , and Public Wellbeing (RENEW) - Evaluating Biogas Transformation in Eastern NC
project_description:
DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO CHARACTERIZE THE ENVIRONMENTAL, PUBLIC HEALTH, ECONOMIC, AND ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE (EJ) IMPACTS OF A LARGE-SCALE SWINE WASTE-TO-ENERGY (SWE) OPERATION IN EASTERN NORTH CAROLINA. ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL 1) USE STAKEHOLDER SURVEYS, INTERVIEWS, AND ECONOMIC ANALYSES TO QUANTITATIVELY AND QUALITATIVELY ASSESS RISK PERCEPTIONS AND SOCIAL, ECONOMIC, AND EJ CONSIDERATIONS RELATED TO SWE; 2) COLLECT AIR, PRIVATE WELL WATER, AND SURFACE WATER SAMPLES BEFORE AND DURING CONSTRUCTION, AND AFTER COMPLETION OF A PLANNED SWE OPERATION; 3) SPATIOTEMPORALLY EVALUATE IMPACTS OF SWE OPERATIONS ON AIR AND WATER QUALITY OF ADJACENT COMMUNITIES, AND COMPARE SWE WITH OTHER ALTERNATIVE ENERGY SOURCES; AND 4) USE THE FINDINGS TO FACILITATE MULTISECTORAL DIALOGUE AND EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES RELATED TO SWE. SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARDEE ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE COMMUNITY ACTION NETWORK (EJCAN) WILL ASSIST IN THE COMMUNITY SAMPLING EFFORTS, ESTABLISH AN EJCAN COMMUNITY LABORATORY FOR ANALYSIS OF WATER SAMPLES, AND COORDINATE COMMUNITY-LED STAKEHOLDER WORKSHOPS. THE REQUESTED AMOUNT IS $233,410.

SUBAWARDEE UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHAPEL HILL (UNC) WILL BE INVOLVED IN CONDUCTING THE ANALYSIS OF COMMUNITY AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS RISK PERCEPTIONS AND ASSIST WITH SITE SELECTION AND DATA ANALYSIS OF ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING DATA. THE REQUESTED AMOUNT IS $299,839.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS AS WELL AS AN EASY-TO-USE, INTERACTIVE TOOL DESIGNED TO HELP COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS CONSIDER HOW SWE OPERATIONS AFFECT CLIMATE, AIR QUALITY, AND OTHER ENVIRONMENTAL GOALS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL, AND ECONOMIC FINDINGS THAT WILL BE OF INTEREST TO COMMUNITIES WITH EJ CONCERNS AS WELL AS ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH PRACTITIONERS AND DECISION-MAKERS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE RESIDENTS IN SAMPSON AND DUPLIN COUNTIES IN EASTERN NORTH CAROLINA, DECISION MAKERS CONCERNED ABOUT THE IMPACTS OF SWINE WASTE-TO-ENERGY (SWE) OPERATIONS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

project_title: Evaluating the Environmental, Behavioral, and Financial Benefits of Electrification and Energy Efficiency for Underserved Communities
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP AN ENERGY-JUSTICE MODEL FOR FREIGHT VEHICLE ELECTRIFICATION IN AN URBAN ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE COMMUNITY THAT IS RESPONSIVE TO COMMUNITY NEEDS WHILE ADVANCING SCIENCE IN AIR QUALITY, PUBLIC HEALTH, SOCIOECONOMIC, ORGANIZATIONAL, AND INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS THAT PLAY A ROLE IN ASSESSING BENEFITS AND COSTS OF TRANSITIONING INTO FREIGHT VEHICLE ELECTRIFICATION.ACTIVITIES:THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE: 1) ANALYZE THE SOCIOTECHNICAL REGIME IN WHICH A TRANSITION TO ELECTRIFIED FREIGHT VEHICLES WILL OCCUR; 2) EVALUATE POTENTIAL SCENARIOS FOR SUCH A TRANSITION IN TERMS OF THEIR REDUCTION IN AIR EMISSIONS; AND 3) DETERMINE THE HEALTH BENEFITS OF SUCH A TRANSITION FOR A COMMUNITY THAT IS HEAVILY IMPACTED BY FREIGHT VEHICLE TRAFFIC. SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARDEE UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS CHICAGO WILL LEAD THE WORK ON BASELINE EXPOSURE ASSESSMENT, ELECTRIFICATION SCENARIO ANALYSIS OF EMISSION MODELING, AIR DISPERSION MODELING, AND EXPOSURE AND HEALTH IMPACTS ASSESSMENT. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS CHICAGO WILL ALSO BE INVOLVED IN RECRUITING COMMUNITY PARTICIPANTS, MOBILE SENSOR TRAINING, AND BASELINE AIR MONITORING DATA COLLECTION.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS. OTHER EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE A COMMUNITY AIR MONITORING AND EXPOSURE ASSESSMENT PLAN (AMEAP); COMMUNITY AIR MONITORING GUIDANCE MATERIALS FOR LOW-COST SENSORS; A DATA REPOSITORY THAT CONTAINS A VARIETY OF ENVIRONMENTAL AND TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTED BY THE PROJECT; A HOLISTIC ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ANALYSIS TOOL KIT; AND AN ONLINE MAPPING TOOL FOR COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE IMPROVED ABILITY TO PREDICT THE POTENTIAL PUBLIC HEALTH AND AIR QUALITY RISK TRADEOFFS IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES DUE TO THE FREIGHT ELECTRIFICATION-RELATED ENERGY TRANSITIONS; AND ENHANCED SOCIOECONOMIC, CULTURAL, AND BEHAVIORAL INSIGHTS THAT CAN INFORM FUTURE ELECTRIFICATION SCENARIOS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE RESIDENTS OF THE LITTLE VILLAGE NEIGHBORHOOD IN SOUTHWEST CHICAGO AND SIMILAR COMMUNITIES SITUATED NEAR FREIGHT RAILS AS WELL AS RESEARCHERS WORKING WITH SIMILAR COMMUNITIES TO ADDRESS ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS ASSOCIATED WITH LARGE-SCALE CHANGES IN ENERGY AND TRANSPORTATION SYSTEMS.

project_title: Evaluating the Environmental, Behavioral, and Financial Benefits of Electrification and Energy Efficiency for Underserved Communities
project_description:
DESCRIPTION:THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO 1) INVESTIGATE HOW ELECTRIFYING AND WEATHERIZING HOMES REDUCES ENERGY USAGE, WHILE PROVIDING ENERGY SECURITY, AMELIORATING THE INDOOR AIR QUALITY OF RESIDENTIAL DWELLINGS, AND IMPROVING COMFORT AND PRODUCTIVITY OF OCCUPANTS; AND 2) IDENTIFY THE BARRIERS TO ADOPTING ELECTRIFICATION AND WEATHERIZATION IN LOW-INCOME HOMES. ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON THE TRI-STATE, TEN COUNTY AREA OF GREATER CINCINNATI AND WILL: 1) ANALYZE THE EFFECTS OF COMBINED ELECTRIFICATION AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY, AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY ALONE, ON HOUSEHOLD ENERGY CONSUMPTION, SECURITY, AND BEHAVIOR IN LOW-INCOME MULTIFAMILY DWELLING UNITS; 2) ESTIMATE THE BENEFITS OF ELECTRIFICATION AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY TECHNOLOGIES ON INDOOR AIR POLLUTION EMISSIONS IN LOW-INCOME MULTIFAMILY DWELLING UNITS; AND 3) EVALUATE THE FACTORS THAT DRIVE AND INHIBIT HOUSEHOLD, MUNICIPAL, AND REGIONAL DECISIONS ABOUT WHETHER TO ADOPT ELECTRIFICATION AND ENERGY EFFICIENT TECHNOLOGIES, RESPECTIVELY, AND TO DO SO SPECIFICALLY FOR UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS. SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARDEE INDIANA UNIVERSITY ($278,190) WILL LEAD THE DESIGN, IMPLEMENTATION, AND ANALYSIS OF THE HOUSEHOLD SURVEYS AND ENERGY DIARIES. 

SUBAWARDEE CARNEGIE MELLON UNIVERSITY (CMU) ($129,674) WILL LEAD THE ANALYSIS OF THE ENERGY EFFICIENCY BENEFITS OF ELECTRIFICATION AND WEATHERIZATION. CMU WILL ALSO LEAD THE ANALYSIS OF AIR QUALITY CHANGES AFTER ELECTRIFICATION. 

SUBAWARDEE OVER-THE-RHINE COMMUNITY HOUSING (OTRCH) ($466,800) WILL SUPPORT THE PROJECT BY LEADING THE BUILDING AND UNIT SELECTION AS WELL AS TENANT RECRUITMENT AND ONGOING ENGAGEMENT EFFORTS. OTRCH WILL ALSO CONDUCT THE PROCUREMENT PROCESS TO SECURE CONTRACTORS TO COMPLETE BUILDING INTERVENTIONS AND OVERSEE THE EXECUTION OF THE WORK.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL PROGRESS AND FINAL REPORTS AS WELL AS JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS DOCUMENTING THE RESEARCH FINDINGS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE EXTENSIVE SOCIOECONOMIC AND BEHAVIORAL INSIGHTS THAT CAN BE USED TO UNDERSTAND AND ADVANCE THE DIFFUSION OF LOW-CARBON AND EFFICIENT TECHNOLOGIES AMONG LOW-INCOME HOUSEHOLDS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE MULTIFAMILY HOME RESIDENTS IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES IN CINCINNATI, OH; LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

project_title: Implementation of Cost-Effective Techniques for the Monitoring & Reduction of Indoor Air Pollutant Exposures in Classroom Environments through a Service-Learning Framework
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO MONITOR INDOOR CONCENTRATIONS OF PARTICULATE MATTER, VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUNDS (VOCS), CARBON DIOXIDE (CO2 ), OZONE (O3 ), AND AIRBORNE PATHOGENS IN A CLASSROOM SETTING UTILIZING INEXPENSIVE CLOUD-BASED AIR QUALITY SENSORS. THIS PROJECT ALSO AIMS TO DESIGN AND INTRODUCE A NON-INVASIVE INDOOR AIR POLLUTANT SOLUTION TO MITIGATE EXPOSURE. ACTIVITIES:THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO 1) EXAMINE EXPOSURE TO INDOOR AIR POLLUTANTS EMPLOYING COST EFFECTIVE APPROACHES FOR OBSERVATION IN REAL-TIME; 2) EVALUATE CLASSROOM POLLUTANT DATA TO RECORD POLLUTION SOURCE AND LOSS PROCESSES; 3) EMPLOY A VIABLE ENGINEERING DESIGN PROCESS TO DEVELOP A COST-EFFECTIVE MITIGATION STRATEGY BASED ON PORTABLE AIR FILTRATION TECHNOLOGY; 4) COMPARE AIR FILTERED BY THE NEWLY DEVELOPED STRATEGIES WITH UNFILTERED AIR TO COMPILE MULTIPOLLUTANT DATASETS; AND 5) IMPLEMENT NEW SERVICE-LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS TO LEARN.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE A FINAL REPORT AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF A COST-EFFICIENT FRAMEWORK FOR INDOOR AIR POLLUTANT MONITORING AND MITIGATION USING MODULAR PORTABLE AIR FILTRATION DEVICES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE LAFAYETTE, INDIANA SCHOOL FACULTY AND STUDENTS, HUMAN HEALTH, THE ENVIRONMENT AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

project_title: MINTS: Multi-scale Intelligent Sensing
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BUILD A NETWORK OF LOW-COST CALIBRATED AIR QUALITY SENSORS THAT CAN BE DISTRIBUTED AT SCALE AND USED SUSTAINABLY ACROSS PREDOMINANT BLACK AND BROWN DALLAS-FORT WORTH NEIGHBORHOODS. THE NETWORK OF LOW-COST SENSORS WILL BE RELATED TO REAL-TIME REMOTE SENSING OBSERVATIONS FROM THE GEOSTATIONARY GOES-R SATELLITE THAT WILL PROVIDE SCIENTIFICALLY VALID INFORMATION FOR DATA-DRIVEN DECISIONS BY COMMUNITIES AND RESIDENTS.ACTIVITIES:THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO : 1) CALIBRATE EACH INDIVIDUAL LOW-COST SENSOR BY CO-LOCATION USING REAL-TIME MACHINE LEARNING TO LINK AND CONTINUOUSLY CALIBRATE A NETWORK OF SENSORS; 2) PARTNERING WITH PAUL QUINN COLLEGE AND DOWNWINDERS AT RISK TO IDENTIFY MOST URGENT LOCATIONS FOR SENSORS; 3) DEVELOP AND DEPLOY INEXPENSIVE SOLAR POWERED SENSORS THAT CAN COMMUNICATE USING LONG RANGE WIRELESS AREA NETWORK; AND 4) DISSEMINATE DATA IN AN OPEN-SOURCE PLATFORM TO THE WEST DALLAS COMMUNITIES.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE A FINAL REPORT AND DEVELOP AN OPEN SENSOR DESIGN AND OPEN SOURCE PARADIGM FOR USING MACHINE LEARNING FOR THE CALIBRATION OF BOTH LOW-COST SENSORS AND REMOTE SENSING SATELLITE OBSERVATIONS FROM NOAA GOES-R, SO THAT THEY CAN READILY AND SUSTAINABLY BE DEPLOYED ACROSS COMMUNITIES AND PROVIDE SCIENTIFICALLY USEFUL AND SOCIETALLY BENEFICIAL MONITORING. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL ENVIRONMENTAL REGULATORS, STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, LOCAL COMMUNITY GROUPS, THE DALLAS-FORT WORTH AREA AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

project_title: Physicochemical Degradation of Microplastics
organization: BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO MEASURE THE RELEASE OF MICROPLASTICS FROM SYNTHETIC TEXTILES DURING WASHING AND EXAMINE THE NANOSCALE DEGRADATION MECHANISMS UNDER SIMULATED ENVIRONMENTAL EXPOSURE THAT MICROPLASTICS ENCOUNTER UPON RELEASE TO NATURAL WATER BODIES.ACTIVITIES:THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO INVESTIGATE THE RELEASE OF MICROPLASTICS FROM SYNTHETIC TEXTILES, OBSERVE MECHANISTIC BREAKDOWN OF THE RELEASED PLASTICS UNDER ENVIRONMENTALLY RELATED CONDITIONS, AND QUANTIFY NANOSCALE DEGRADATION USING A QUARTZ-CRYSTAL MICROBALANCE.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE A FINAL REPORT AS WELL AS DOCUMENTING THE FINDINGS OF RELEASE PATTERN OF MICROPLASTICS DURING WASHING, DEGRADATION BEHAVIOR UNDER VISIBLE LIGHT AND HYDROLYSIS IN THE AQUATIC ENVIRONMENT, AND MASS CHANGE DURING DEGRADATION AT THE NANOSCALE LEVEL. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THE PROGRAM INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT PERSONNEL, HUMAN HEALTH, THE ENVIRONMENT, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

project_title: Enhanced Detection and Removal of GenX from Water Supplies
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A MORE EFFECTIVE AND SUSTAINABLE METHOD FOR DETECTION AND REMOVAL OF GENX FROM WATER.ACTIVITIES:THE ACTIVITIES PERFORMED WILL ADDRESS DECREASED SENSITIVITY OF GENX DETECTION DUE TO BACKGROUND LEVELS IN SAMPLE BLANKS AND EFFECTIVE DISPOSAL OF WASTE PRODUCED BY THE CLEANSING OF ANION EXCHANGE RESINS USED IN THE REMOVAL OF GENX AT WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANTS. THE RECIPIENT WILL PERFORM THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES: 1) TREAT WATER USED IN LC-MS/MS BLANK SAMPLES USING PHOTOCATALYTIC DEGRADATION TO REMOVE ANY BACKGROUND CONTAMINANTS THAT WOULD DECREASE INSTRUMENT SENSITIVITY; 2) TREAT THE WASTE PRODUCT OBTAINED FROM CLEANSING OF ANION EXCHANGE RESINS USING PHOTOCATALYTIC DEGRADATION; AND 3) ASSESS THE SUCCESS OF REMOVAL USING LC-MS/MS TO DETECT CHANGES IN LEVELS OF GENX PRE- AND POST-TREATMENT FOR BOTH THE BLANK SAMPLES AND WASTE PRODUCTS.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE A FINAL REPORT DOCUMENTING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF PHOTOCATALYTIC DEGRADATION TREATMENT IN REDUCING LEVELS OF GENX IN BLANK SAMPLES AND WASTE PRODUCTS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT OPERATORS, RESEARCHERS, CONTAMINATED SITE MANAGERS, HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

project_title: Urban Water Pollution Extent and Impact on the Village Creek in Birmingham, AL - Analysis and Mitigation Strategies
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO ANALYZE THE MOVEMENT OF POLLUTANTS AROUND THE VILLAGE CREEK RIVER, STUDY THE VULNERABILITY OF THE COMMUNITIES LIVING ALONG THE RIVER AND IN THE FLOOD-RISK ZONES, AND PROMOTE THE INCLUSION OF LOW IMPACT DEVELOPMENTS AND GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE TO MITIGATE THE ISSUE.ACTIVITIES:THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO 1) PROVIDE A PLATFORM FOR THE PUBLIC TO ACCESS INFORMATION REGARDING THE POLLUTANT EXPOSURE AND HIGH-RISK AREAS IN AN EASILY UNDERSTANDABLE FORMAT AND 2) PROPOSE MODIFIED MITIGATION STRATEGIES SUCH AS FLOATING GARDENS, POLLUTION ABSORBING RAIN GARDENS, AND BIOSWALES IN THE IMPACTED COMMUNITIES.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE A FINAL REPORT ALONG WITH A VULNERABILITY HAZARD MAP THAT WILL IDENTIFY THE COMMUNITIES AT RISK OF EXPOSURE TO POLLUTANTS, AN INFORMATIVE WEBSITE PROVIDING INFORMATION REGARDING THE TYPE OF POLLUTANTS IN THE AREA AND MODIFIED LOW IMPACT DEVELOPMENTS AND GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE DESIGN. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE COMMUNITY MEMBERS NEAR THE VILLAGE CREEK RIVER, CITY PLANNERS, HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT.

project_title: Three-Way Removal of Per- and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances from High-Strength Landfill Leachate Utilizing Simultaneous Foaming and Humic Acid Precipitation During pH Adjustment
project_description: DESCRIPTION:LANDFILL LEACHATE IS ONE OF THE MAJOR SOURCES OF PER- AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS) TO THE ENVIRONMENT. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO (I) EVALUATE THE EFFECT OF SIMPLE PH ADJUSTMENT ON PFAS REMOVAL DUE TO HUMIC ACID PRECIPITATION AND FOAMING AT LOW PH, (II) EVALUATE THE PERFORMANCE OF A MEMBRANE ELECTROCHEMICAL REACTOR TO REMOVE PFAS IN PRECIPITATED HUMIC ACID AND FOAM AT LOW PH IN THE ANODE CHAMBER, AND (III) EVALUATE PRELIMINARY TREATMENTS OF COALESCED FOAM, HUMIC ACIDS, AND THE REMAINING FRACTION OF LEACHATE FOR PFAS DESTRUCTION.ACTIVITIES:THE STUDENT TEAM WILL DEVELOP QUANTITATIVE DATA OF REAGENT AND ENERGY REQUIREMENTS AND TREATMENT PERFORMANCE FOR THE PROPOSED TECHNOLOGIES. A COMPLETE UNDERSTANDING OF THE EFFECT OF PFAS CHEMICAL PROPERTIES (E.G., HEADGROUPS, CHAIN LENGTH, THE EXTENT OF FLUORINATION) ON THE SEPARATION AND REMOVAL DURING TREATMENT WILL BE DEVELOPED. THE MECHANISTIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE IMPACT OF CHEMICAL PROPERTIES ON REMOVAL WILL HELP RESEARCHERS DEVELOP PROPER TREATMENTS FOR PFAS COMPOUNDS BASED ON THEIR PROPERTIES. THE TEAM WILL ALSO IDENTIFY THE EFFECTIVE CONDITIONS FOR THERMAL TREATMENT OF PFAS CONTAINING HUMIC ACID.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THE PROJECT EXPECTS TO PRODUCE A COMPLETE UNDERSTANDING OF THE TREATMENT MECHANISMS AND CHEMICAL PROPERTIES OF PFAS WITHIN LANDFILL LEACHATES TO IMPROVE ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH. SPECIFICALLY, THE RESULTS WILL INCLUDE A COMPARISON OF THE TREATMENT PERFORMANCE AMONG HIGH-STRENGTH LEACHATE, FOAM, AND DEFOAMED LEACHATE IN THE GAC+UV/SULFITE PROCESS; A COMPLETE MASS BALANCE OF PFAS SPECIES IN THE TREATMENT SYSTEM; AND AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE BYPRODUCTS FORMED DURING DESTRUCTIVE TREATMENTS (I.E., THERMAL, MER, UV/ARP). DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS WORK INCLUDE COMMUNITIES IMPACTED BY PFAS CONTAMINATION, LANDFILL AND WASTE MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS, AND STATE AND LOCAL WATER RESOURCE MANAGERS.

project_title: Modelling Outdoor Comfort with UAV-based Digitization Technique and a Comfort Tracking System for Underserved Communities.
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CREATE A TRACKING SYSTEM THAT COMBINES HEAT AND AIR POLLUTION EFFECTS AT THE NEAR SURFACE OR LOCALIZED MICROCLIMATIC CONDITIONS TO MEASURE A COMFORT INDEX VALUE WITHIN VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES. ACTIVITIES:TO CREATE A COMFORT INDEX, THE PROJECT WILL 1) DEPLOY DRONE MAPPING OF THE BUILT ENVIRONMENT IN SELECTED NEIGHBORHOODS MOST AT RISK FROM AIR POLLUTANTS AND HIGH TEMPERATURES, 2) USE MODELING TOOLS TO SIMULATE THE URBAN MICRO-CLIMATE, INCLUDING HEAT AND AIR POLLUTION, FOR REAL-TIME SIMULATION OF CONDITIONS THAT INDIVIDUALS EXPERIENCE, AND 3) ENGAGE COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO MONITOR POLLUTION DATA USING SMALL POLLUTION MONITORING DEVICES THAT TRAVEL THROUGH THE SELECTED NEIGHBORHOODS.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE A FINAL REPORT AS WELL AS A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE NEAR SURFACE IMPACT OF INCREASED TEMPERATURE AND AIR POLLUTION ON THE HEALTH OF THE CITY OF BIRMINGHAM, ALABAMA. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE COMMUNITY MEMBERS OF BIRMINGHAM, URBAN PLANNERS AND DESIGNERS, AND STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT.

project_title: Natural Approach in Antifouling Protection: Remedy for Safer Water for Fisherman, Boaters, and Cargo Ships
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO DEMONSTRATE THE EFFICACY OF NATURAL EXTRACTS FORMULATIONS IN ANTIFOULING PROTECTION USING A CUSTOM MODEL AQUARIUM WHICH WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH OF MARINE ENVIRONMENTS BY REDUCING THE TRANSMISSION OF BIOFILM GENERATING BACTERIA BY BOATS AND SHIPS BEYOND THEIR NATURAL HABITAT TO AREAS WHERE IT IS INVASIVE AND CAUSES UNCONTROLLED ALGAE BLOOM AND CONTRIBUTES TO FISH AND CRAB MORTALITY.ACTIVITIES:THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO (1) BUILD PILOT AQUARIUMS FOR LONG TERM TESTING OF NEW ANTIFOULING FORMULATIONS ON DIFFERENT TYPES OF SUBMERGED SURFACES; (2) DEMONSTRATE THE EFFECTIVENESS AND CONDUCT A PILOT STUDY OF THE CONCEPT OF USE OF NATURAL EXTRACTS ENCAPSULATED INTO BIOCOMPATIBLE POLYMERS FOR ANTIFOULING PROTECTION OF SUBMERGED SURFACES; AND (3) EVALUATE IN LONG TERM EXPERIMENTS HOW WATER TYPE AND PARAMETERS, AS WELL AS TYPE OF PLANT MATERIALS, POLYMERS AND SOLVENTS INFLUENCE THE ABILITY OF THE COATING TO PROTECT AGAINST BIOFOULING.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE A FINAL REPORT, AS WELL AS IMPROVE HUMAN WELL-BEING BY AVOIDING CONTAMINATION OF MARINE ENVIRONMENTS FROM PRODUCTS OF BIOFOULING AND INVASIVE BACTERIA AND HELP TO AVOID UNCONTROLLED ALGAE BLOOMS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE RURAL FISHERMEN, SMALL FARMERS, RECREATIONAL BOATERS, HUMAN HEALTH, THE ENVIRONMENT AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

project_title: Integrated Portable Raman and Electrochemical NanoSystem (I-PRENS) for Neonicotinoid Detection and Remediation in Rural Drinking Water Supplies
project_description:
DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A PORTABLE RAMAN AND ELECTROCHEMICAL NANOSYSTEM (I-PRENS) TO BE DEPLOYED FOR ONSITE DETECTION AND DEGRADATION OF NEONICOTINOID PESTICIDES IN RURAL DRINKING WATER SUPPLIES IN ALABAMA'S BLACK BELT REGION.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL APPLY THE BEST-AVAILABLE NANOTECHNOLOGY-ENABLED SENSING AND TREATMENT TECHNOLOGIES INTO A FIELD-DEPLOYABLE PROTOTYPE DESIGNED FOR LONG-TERM MONITORING AND CHEMICAL-SUPPLY-FREE REMEDIATION OF NEONICOTINOID-IMPACTED DRINKING WATER SUPPLIES. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO (1) DEVELOP A HOT SPOT NORMALIZED SURFACE-ENHANCED RAMAN SPECTROSCOPIC (HSN-SERS) SENSING MODULE FOR REAL-TIME QUANTIFICATION OF NEONICOTINOIDS; (2) DEVELOP A NANOBIOCHAR-ENABLED PRE-TREATMENT MODULE FOR NEONICOTINOID PRE-CONCENTRATION; (3) DEVELOP A SENSOR-CONTROLLED CATALYTIC ADVANCED OXIDATION PROCESS (AOP) MODULE FOR NEONICOTINOID DEGRADATION; AND (4) DEVELOP AND DEPLOY A SMALL-SCALE I-PRENS PROTOTYPE IN RURAL ALABAMA.SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARD OF $490,241 TO YALE UNIVERSITY WILL SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF A SENSOR-CONTROLLED CATALYTIC ADVANCED OXIDATION PROCESS (AOP) MODULE FOR NEONICOTINOID DEGRADATION. SUBAWARD OF $379,206 TO AUBURN UNIVERSITY WILL SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF A NANOBIOCHAR-ENABLED PRE-TREATMENT MODULE FOR NEONICOTINOID PRE-CONCENTRATION AND THE DEPLOYMENT OF A PROTOTYPE.
OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS DOCUMENTING THE PROGRESS TOWARD DEVELOPING THE TECHNOLOGY AND RESULTS FROM FIELD DEPLOYMENT. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE RURAL ALABAMA COMMUNITY, COMMUNITIES THAT DEPEND ON PESTICIDE-IMPACTED DRINKING WATER SUPPLIES, PRIVATE/COMMUNITY WELL OWNERS, RESEARCHERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

project_title: Winning the Race Against Competing Risks: Optimizing Drinking Water Disinfection to Minimize Opportunistic Pathogen & DBP Risks
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND AND PREDICT OCCURRENCE OF DISINFECTION BYPRODUCTS, OPPORTUNISTIC PATHOGENS AND THE ASSOCIATED HEALTH RISK TRADEOFFS POSED BY THEM IN DRINKING WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS (DWDS) ACROSS THE CONTINENTAL U.S.ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A STRATEGIC MONITORING PROGRAM THROUGH PARTNERSHIP WITH PUBLIC HEALTH DEPARTMENTS AND WATER UTILITY MANAGERS AND ANALYSIS OF HISTORIC DATA TO SAMPLE WATER FOR REGULATED AND UNREGULATED DISINFECTION BYPRODUCTS (DBPS) AND PATHOGENS. THE RESEARCH WILL ALSO CONDUCT A CHEMICAL AND QUANTITATIVE MICROBIAL RISK ASSESSMENT AND EVALUATION OF RISK-RISK TRADEOFFS CONSIDERING TEMPORAL, SPATIAL AND POPULATION DYNAMICS.SUBRECIPIENT:OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY ($115,121 EPA, $28,794 COST SHARE) WILL HELP TO COMPLETE THE MICROBIAL RISK ASSESSMENTS AND LEAD THE RISK TRADE-OFF EVALUATION. DREXEL UNIVERSITY ($41,278 EPA, $9,945 COST SHARE) WILL PROVIDE DEEP EXPERTISE AND EXPERIENCE IN WATER DISINFECTION AND RISK ASSESSMENT. THE COLLEGE OF NEW JERSEY ($102,042 EPA, $33,000 COST SHARE) WILL LEAD EFFORTS TO EVALUATE HISTORIC EPIDEMIOLOGICAL AND MONITORING DATA TO SUPPORT DEVELOPMENT OF A STRATEGIC SAMPLING PLAN AND ASSIST WITH THE RISK TRADE-OFF EVALUATION. CLEMSON UNIVERSITY ($716,806 EPA, $178,820 COST SHARE) WILL LEAD THE ANALYTICAL ASSESSMENT OF REGULATED AND UNREGULATED DBPS IN DRINKING WATER SAMPLES COLLECTED IN THE PROJECT TO EVALUATE OCCURRENCE AND CONCENTRATIONS. TULANE UNIVERSITY ($670,129 EPA, $167,431 COST SHARE) WILL LEAD THE MICROBIAL WATER QUALITY ANALYSIS FOR OPPORTUNISTIC PATHOGENS AND OTHER RELEVANT PARAMETERS IN DRINKING WATER SAMPLES COLLECTED IN THE PROJECT TO DETERMINE OCCURRENCE AND CONCENTRATIONS OF SPECIES OF INTEREST. THE NY STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH ($46,000 EPA, $11,250 COST SHARE) WILL PARTICIPATE IN THE SELECTION AND EVALUATION OF HEALTH OUTCOME AND MONITORING DATA RELATED TO LEGIONELLA IN NY STATE. THEY WILL PROVIDE RESEARCH DIRECTION ON STRATEGIC SAMPLING IN LOCATIONS WITHIN DWDS THAT MAY BE OF PARTICULAR CONCERN FOR SAMPLING. ADDITIONALLY, THEY WILL COORDINATE SAMPLING WITHIN NY STATE WATER SYSTEMS.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE PUBLICATIONS, RISK MODELS, AND DATA TO INFORM DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO HOST WORKSHOPS AND ONLINE COMMUNICATIONS TO ENGAGE STAKEHOLDERS AS WELL AS DEVELOP TOOLKIT FOR COMMUNICATIONS OUTREACH. THE OUTCOME OF THIS WORK WILL ENABLE MOVEMENT AWAY FROM ROUTINE MONITORING FOR THESE HAZARDS TOWARDS TOOLS FOR MORE COMPREHENSIVE WATER SYSTEM EVALUATION, RISK-BASED AND PRIORITIZED MONITORING STRATEGIES BASED ON DRINKING WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM CHARACTERISTICS, AND THE BIOLOGICAL, CHEMICAL, AND PHYSICAL PARAMETERS MOST LIKELY TO LEAD TO ELEVATED RISKS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE RESIDENTS OF NEW YORK, STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, WATER UTILITY MANAGERS, AND SITE MANAGERS AND OPERATORS.

project_title: Innovations in Sampling, (Bio)analytical Chemistry, and Analytics to Characterize Disinfectant Use Tradeoffs in U.S. Water Systems for Minimizing Exposure to Opportunistic Pathogens and DBPs
organization: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA
project_description:
DESCRIPTION:THIS APPLICATION PROPOSES A HIGHLY INNOVATIVE PROJECT TO ASSESS THE TRADEOFFS BETWEEN OPPORTUNISTIC PATHOGENS (OPS) AND DISINFECTION BY-PRODUCTS (DBPS) AND DEVELOP STRATEGIES FOR LIMITING EXPOSURE TO BOTH CLASSES OF WATER CONTAMINANTS VIA U.S. DRINKING WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS. 
ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL QUANTIFY AND ASSESS OPS, REGULATED DBPS, AND UNREGULATED DBPS. SUBRECIPIENT:TOWSON UNIVERSITY ($377,267 EPA, $94,320 COST SHARE) WILL PERFORM DBP ANALYSES. JOHNS HOPKINS ($424,851 EPA, $233,427 COST SHARE) WILL PERFORM NON-TARGET DBP ANALYSIS AND TOXICITY TESTING. UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA, FAIRBANKS ($321,820 EPA, $80,455 COST SHARE) WILL PERFORM DATA ANALYTICS AND MODELING.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL PROGRESS AND FINAL REPORTS, PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS, AND CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE WATER UTILITIES AND COMMUNITIES SERVED BY WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS THROUGHOUT THE U.S.

project_title: Integrated Water Microbiome and Disinfection Byproducts Monitoring and Management to Advance Drinking Water Quality
project_description:
DESCRIPTION:THE OVERALL GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO DEVELOP AN INTEGRATED FRAMEWORK TO QUANTITATIVELY MONITOR THE DRINKING WATER MICROBIOME, INCLUDING WATERBORNE PATHOGENS (WPS) AND DISINFECTION BYPRODUCTS (DBPS), AND HOLISTICALLY MANAGE WP AND DBP RISKS IN DRINKING WATER STORAGE AND DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS (DWSDSS) USING INCLUSIVE AND ACTIONABLE RISK METRICS.ACTIVITIES:THIS GOAL OF AN INTEGRATED FRAMEWORK WILL BE REALIZED THROUGH TWO RESEARCH OBJECTIVES: (1) ENACTING COMPREHENSIVE SPATIAL-TEMPORAL MONITORING AND CHARACTERIZATION OF WATER CHEMISTRY AND MICROBIOLOGY OF MULTIPLE FULL-SCALE DWSDSS IN DIFFERENT REGIONS OF THE COUNTRY; AND (2) FORMULATING AN INTEGRATED AND ACTIONABLE RISK ASSESSMENT AND MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORK TO MITIGATE WP AND DBP RISKS AND IDENTIFY THE UNDERLYING TRADE-OFFS TO OPTIMIZE DRINKING WATER QUALITY IN DWSDSS.SUBRECIPIENT:THE WATER TOWER INSTITUTE ($414,800 FEDERAL, $108,600 COST SHARE) WILL SERVE ON THE PROJECT AS THE UTILITY LIAISON FOR THE TEAM. TWTI PLANS TO PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR QUALITY ASSURANCE/QUALITY CONTROL, DATA MANAGEMENT, SAMPLING AND SHIPPING LOGISTICS, AND CHEMICAL AND MICROBIAL ANALYSES TO ENSURE THE SUCCESSFUL AND TIMELY COMPLETION OF THE PROJECT. NORTHEASTERN UNIVERSITY ($461,763  FEDERAL, $144,299 COST SHARE) WILL PROVIDE EXPERTISE ON ORGANIC GEOCHEMISTRY, DOM CYCLING AND TRANSFORMATIONS, AND EXPERIMENTAL AND MODELING APPROACHES; CHARACTERIZING CHEMICAL AND MICROBIAL CONTAMINANTS IN DRINKING WATER IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES; AND FUNDAMENTAL MASS SPECTROMETRY; AND WILL LEAD THE ORGANIC MATTER ANALYSES AND THE INTEGRATION OF ORGANIC MATTER DATA INTO THE PROJECT. UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA ($395,778 FEDERAL, $98,945 COST SHARE) WILL LEAD THE DEVELOPMENT, APPLICATION, AND INTERPRETATION OF COMPARATIVE (CHEMICAL, MICROBIAL) QUANTITATIVE RISK ASSESSMENT APPROACHES TO UNDERSTANDING RISKS IN WATER UTILITIES.
OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS, AS WELL AS A UNIQUE DATASET THAT CONCURRENTLY QUANTIFIES WPS AND REGULATED AND UNREGULATED DBPS IN A DIVERSE RANGE OF DWSDSS AND PUTS THIS DATA IN RICH CONTEXT WITH A THOROUGH CHARACTERIZATION OF WATER CHEMISTRY AND MICROBIOLOGY. ADDITIONALLY, THEY WILL DEVELOP AN INTEGRATED FRAMEWORK TO QUANTITATIVELY MONITOR THE DRINKING WATER MICROBIOME, INCLUDING WPS AND DBPS. THEY WILL ALSO DEVELOP A RISK MANAGEMENT TOOLKIT, PUBLICATIONS, AND CONFERENCES TO DISSEMINATE THEIR FINDINGS. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE WATER UTILITY MANAGERS AND COMMUNITIES WHO GET THEIR WATER FROM PUBLIC DRINKING WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS.

project_title: Co-DOWN: Consortium on Disinfection By-Products and Opportunistic Pathogens in Water Networks
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT AIMS TO ACHIEVE A NATIONWIDE STUDY OF THE PREVALENCE OF OPPORTUNISTIC PATHOGENS, THEIR FREE-LIVING AMOEBAE VECTORS, AND REGULATED AND UNREGULATED DISINFECTION BYPRODUCTS ACROSS A WIDE VARIETY OF SIZES AND TYPES OF DRINKING WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS (DWDS).ACTIVITIES:MULTI-TIERED PARTNERSHIPS ACROSS APPROXIMATELY 100 DRINKING WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS WILL BE DEVELOPED TO ACHIEVE THE OBJECTIVES, INCLUDING EDUCATIONAL COMPONENTS THAT WILL BE USED TO PROVIDE DIRECT APPLICATION OF THE RESEARCH TO OTHER UTILITIES. UTILITY PARTNERS WILL ASSIST WITH PERFORMING ONE SAMPLING EVENT PER YEAR FROM 5-10 LOCATIONS IN THEIR DRINKING WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS.SUBRECIPIENT:UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS ($399,691 EPA, $101,095 COST SHARE) WILL TAKE THE TECHNICAL LEAD ON DBP ANALYSES AND OP/DBP RISK ASSESSMENT. UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN ($425,000 EPA, $143,080 COST SHARE) WILL TAKE THE TECHNICAL LEAD ON THE FLUSHING STUDY AS WELL AS THE COCREATION OF LEARNING MODULES BASED ON THE RESEARCH FINDINGS. GEORGE WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY ($240,000 EPA, $60,000 COST SHARE) WILL TAKE THE TECHNICAL LEAD ON BEST PRACTICES FOR ASSESSING OPPORTUNISTIC PATHOGEN VIABILITY. THE WATER TOWER INSTITUTE: ($30,000) WILL ASSIST WITH RECRUITING AND INTERACTING WITH UTILITY PARTNERS, WORK WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN TEAM TO COCREATE LEARNING MODULES, HOST ONE OF THE BIOSTUDY EXPERIMENTS, AND HOST TWO IN PERSON MEETINGS/WORKSHOPS AT THEIR WATER CAMPUS.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE ANNUAL PROGRESS AND FINAL REPORTS, A SURVEY OF THE PATHOGENS AND VECTORS IN THE SAMPLED WATER SYSTEMS, MITIGATION STRATEGIES, AND LEARNING MODULES. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO DEVELOP A RISK FRAMEWORK, AND A PLAN TO COMMUNICATE RISKS AS WELL AS GUIDANCE FOR A MODIFIED SYSTEM FLUSHING PROGRAM. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE DRINKING WATER UTILITIES AND CONSUMERS WHOSE DRINKING WATER COMES FROM PUBLIC DRINKING WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS.

project_title: Grant to NATIONAL INDIAN HEALTH BOARD
project_description:
DESCRIPTION:THE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FUNDING TO THE NATIONAL INDIAN HEALTH BOARD (NIHB).  SPECIFICALLY, THE NATIONAL INDIAN HEALTH BOARD WILL SERVE AS A NATIONAL EJ TCTAC PROVIDING SERVICES RELATED TO ENVIRONMENTAL AND ENERGY JUSTICE AT THE TRIBAL LEVEL. LIKE ALL NIHB PROJECTS, THE EJ TCTAC WILL COVER THE NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC AREA AND SERVE TRIBES THROUGHOUT THE UNITED STATES. NIHB WILL LEVERAGE THE 2018-2019 ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH DISCUSSION SESSIONS AND THE 2021- 2022 REGIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SUMMITS HOSTED BY NIHB AND SUPPORTED BY CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION (CDC) TO ADDRESS ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE CONCERNS IN INDIAN COUNTRY, SUCH AS THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE; EXTERNAL POLLUTANTS IN THE AIR, LAND, AND WATER; SUPERFUND SITES; SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL ISSUES, AND THE TRANSITION TO CLEAN ENERGY SOURCES. NIHB WILL STAND UP THE TRIBAL EJ TCTAC AS A ONE-STOP SHOP FOR TRIBAL NATIONS LOOKING FOR SUPPORT IN THE ENVIRONMENTAL AND ENERGY JUSTICE SPACES. NIHB WILL LEVERAGE ITS EXISTING FRAMEWORK OF OUTREACH TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF TRIBES APPLYING FOR AND RECEIVING FUNDING FROM FEDERAL AND NON-FEDERAL PARTNERS ON ENVIRONMENTAL AND ENERGY JUSTICE PROJECTS. NIHB WILL PROVIDE GRANT WRITING COURSES, GRANT APPLICATION EXPLAINERS, TARGETED APPLICATION ASSISTANCE, AND PROJECT EVALUATION DESIGN TRAININGS THROUGHOUT INDIAN COUNTRY TO ADDRESS ENVIRONMENTAL AND ENERGY JUSTICE CONCERNS OVER THE COURSE OF THIS PROJECT. NIHB'S EJ TCTAC WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE ON FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES, INCLUDING APPLICATIONS INVOLVING A COHORT OR PARTNERSHIP WITH TRIBES, MUNICIPAL PARTNERS, AND STATE GOVERNMENTS. NIHB WILL DEVELOP A CLEARINGHOUSE OF STATE-BASED GRANTS FOR WHICH TRIBES ARE ELIGIBLE AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE IN THE APPLICATION PROCESS. WITH EPA AND THE DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY'S (DOE) COORDINATION, THE TRIBAL TCTAC WILL ALSO WORK WITH REGIONAL TCTACS TO ENSURE CONSISTENCY, CULTURAL COMPETENCY, AND THE HIGHEST LEVEL OF SERVICE POSSIBLE TO TRIBAL NATIONS. ADDITIONALLY, NIHB WILL WORK WITH TRIBAL GRANTEES TO HIGHLIGHT THEIR SUCCESS STORIES WIDELY THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA, LOOK-BACK REPORTS, AND PUBLIC ANNOUNCEMENTS.ACTIVITIES:THE ACTIVITIES INCLUDE (BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO) THE FOLLOWING: 1) NIHB WILL HOST A FREE FEDERAL GRANT WRITING 101 SEMINAR IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE ANNUAL NATIONAL TRIBAL HEALTH CONFERENCE AND A SECOND IN A SEPARATE LOCATION IN INDIAN COUNTRY. ATTENDEES WILL BE TRAINED IN USING GRANTS.GOV, GRANTSOLUTIONS.GOV, SAM, EERE EXCHANGE, AS WELL AS FAMILIARITY WITH FEDERAL BUDGET TEMPLATES, NARRATIVES, AND SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS; 2) NIHB WILL MONITOR THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY, THE DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY, AND THE DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION FOR ENVIRONMENTAL AND ENERGY JUSTICE FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES OPEN TO TRIBES. NIHB WILL NOTIFY TRIBES AND PROVIDE UNBIASED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR POTENTIAL APPLICANTS IN THE PROCESS OF APPLYING FOR COMPETITIVE GRANTS, INCLUDING A REVIEW OF APPLICATION DRAFTS WITHIN THE LIMITS SET BY THE EJ TCTAC STRUCTURE; 3) NIHB WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR TRIBES APPLYING FOR GRANTS FROM THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT, STATE GOVERNMENTS, AND OTHER PARTNERS. THIS WILL INCLUDE SPECIFIC GUIDANCE ON REGISTERING WITH SAM.GOV, GRANT EXPLAINERS WITH THE TRIBES TO EXAMINE ELIGIBILITY AND POTENTIAL IMPACT, GUIDANCE WITH THE APPLICATION PROCESS, AND REVIEW OF DRAFT GRANT PROPOSALS. NIHB WILL CREATE A CLEARINGHOUSE OF STATE-BASED ENVIRONMENTAL AND HEALTH GRANTS FOR WHICH TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS ARE ELIGIBLE; AND 4) NIHB WILL TRANSLATE MATERIALS INTO LANGUAGES SPOKEN BY A LARGE NUMBER OF AMERICAN INDIANS AND ALASKA NATIVES, SUCH AS DINE (NAVAJO), CHEROKEE, AND YUPIK.SUBRECIPIENT:ACTIVITIES TO BE IMPLEMENTED THROUGH SUBAWARDS INCLUDE FEASIBILITY STUDIES FOR THE TRANSITION AWAY FROM FOSSIL FUEL ELECTRICAL GENERATION ON TRIBAL LANDS AND THE TRANSITION FROM GAS POWERED VEHICLES TO ELECTRICAL VEHICLES IN TRIBAL FLEETS.

project_title: Grant to INSTITUTE FOR SUSTAINABLE COMMUNITIES
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FUNDING TO THE INSTITUTE FOR SUSTAINABLE COMMUNITIES (ISC) TO SERVE AS A NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE THRIVING COMMUNITIES TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CENTER (EJ TCTAC). THE ISC TEAM'S EXPERIENCE AND EXPERTISE OFFER THE NATIONAL EJ TCTAC NETWORK A ROBUST NATIONAL COORDINATION MECHANISM THAT WILL BUILD CAPACITY, REDUCE DUPLICATION, AND USE COMPLEMENTARY SERVICES TO SUPPORT ALL LEVELS OF THE EJ TCTAC PROGRAM. USING ISC'S NETWORKS, INCLUDING ISC'S NATIONAL CLIMATE LEADERS OF COLOR NETWORK AND ASAP'S MEMBERS, THEY WILL ESTABLISH A NATIONAL EJ TCTAC THAT WILL BUILD THE CAPACITY OF REGIONAL TCTACS, LOCAL LEADERS, COMMUNITIES, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE (TA) PROVIDERS THROUGH NEEDS-BASED, VIRTUAL, AND IN-PERSON SUPPORT AND COORDINATED ACTIVITIES, TOOLS, AND RESOURCES. A KEY COMPONENT OF THE NATIONAL TCTAC WILL BE ENSURING THE MEASURABLE SUCCESS OF THE REGIONAL CENTERS. WHEN REGIONAL NEEDS EMERGE, THE TEAM WILL PROVIDE DIRECT SERVICES TO PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS AND COMMUNITIES. IN COORDINATION WITH THE EPA, DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY (DOE), AND REGIONAL CENTER TEAMS, ISC WILL QUICKLY MOBILIZE A NATIONAL CENTER WITH FLEXIBLE, THREE-PRONGED SERVICES THAT CAN ADAPT TO DIVERSE NEEDS THROUGH 1) TAILORED SUPPORT TO REGIONAL TCTACS VIA PEER LEARNING, TOOLS, AND INFORMATION SHARING; 2) SUPPORT TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES USING ISC'S COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT EXPERTISE; AND 3) THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN ONLINE NATIONAL EJ TCTAC PLATFORM FOR INTERACTIVE COMMUNICATION, NETWORKING, COLLABORATION, AND GREATER FUNDING ACCESS. USING THE NATIONAL PLATFORM WEBSITE, SOCIAL MEDIA, DIRECT CONTACT, AND OTHER OUTREACH, ISC WILL CONNECT PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS, TA PROVIDERS, POTENTIAL PARTNERS, THE REGIONAL TCTACS, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS TO EACH OTHER AND FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES. THE ONLINE PLATFORM'S MULTIPLE FUNCTIONS WILL INCLUDE INTEGRATED FEEDBACK MECHANISMS, INTERACTIVE TWO-WAY COMMUNICATION, AND A MEANS TO COMMUNICATE WITH OUR PROJECT TEAM. THE PLATFORM WILL BE FULLY CUSTOMIZABLE TO SERVE THE NEEDS OF EPA, REGIONAL TCTACS, AND PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS AND WILL COMPLY WITH THE AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT. AT A MINIMUM, THE PLATFORM WILL INCLUDE MULTIPLE INTERFACES, INCLUDING 1) PASSWORD-PROTECTED LOGINS FOR PROGRAM PARTICIPANT PROFILES; 2) A SPACE FOR REGIONAL TCTAC STAFF, PARTNERS, AND TA PROVIDERS; AND 3) SPACE FOR INTERACTIVE, TWO-WAY CONVERSATION AND CHAT OPTIONS BETWEEN PARTICIPANTS, REGIONAL CENTERS, AND/OR OTHER STAKEHOLDERS. THE PROFILES WILL BE USED TO PROMOTE VOLUNTEER AND CONTRACTED TA SERVICES AS WELL AS TO STRENGTHEN NETWORKS OF LEADERS AND ROLE MODEL CHAMPIONS. WE WILL COMPLEMENT THESE WITH WEBINARS AND MATERIALS ON PARTNERSHIP AND COALITION BUILDING. THE PLATFORM WILL ALSO HOUSE AN ATTRACTIVE, EASY-TO-USE, AND SEARCHABLE ENVIRONMENTAL AND ENERGY JUSTICE LIBRARY TO SHARE WITH REGIONAL. BY THE END OF YEAR 1, THE ISC TEAM PLANS TO LAUNCH THE ONLINE PLATFORM. ACTIVITIES:THE ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ESTABLISHING AND MAINTAINING THE NATIONAL EJ TCTAC ONLINE PLATFORM, COORDINATION AND PLANNING MEETINGS, OUTREACH ACTIVITIES, NATIONAL AND LOCAL RESOURCE ANALYSES, DEVELOPMENT OF A TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS DATABASE, SUSTAINABILITY PLANNING, COMPILING AND DEVELOPMENT OF RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT TOOLS, MATERIALS, AND PRODUCTS. ADDITIONAL ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CONDUCTING REGIONAL TCTACS NEEDS ASSESSMENTS, PARTNERSHIP FACILITATION, REGIONAL TCTACS TRAINING, DEVELOPMENT OF TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS SUPPORTING PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS' INCREASED ABILITY TO APPLY FOR AND MANAGE GRANTS ADDRESSING ENVIRONMENTAL AND ENERGY JUSTICE ISSUES, INCLUDING (BUT NOT LIMITED TO) AIR POLLUTION AND GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS, THE CLEAN ENERGY TRANSITION, WATER RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, STORMWATER AND FLOODING, AND SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL.  ISC WILL ALSO HOLD BIANNUAL TOPIC BASED WEBINARS/WORKSHOPS, ANNUAL KNOWLEDGE SHARING CONVENINGS, ROLE MODELS AND LEADER WORKSHOPS, AS WELL AS PRIVATE SECTOR ENGAGEMENT AND FIN

project_title: LID Surface Water-Groundwater Interaction Study
project_description:
DESCRIPTION:THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT AIMS TO RESEARCH THE EFFECTIVENESS OF STORMWATER BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS) USED FOR ENHANCED AQUIFER RECHARGE (EAR) TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF URBAN STORMWATER RECHARGING GROUNDWATER SUPPLIES.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL EXAMINE THE IMPACT OF LATERAL EXFILTRATION OF STORMWATER RUNOFF COUPLED WITH VADOSE ZONE STRATIFICATION AND THE IMPACT OF LATERAL FLOW ON POLLUTANT TRANSPORT INTO GROUNDWATER. THE PROJECT WILL PERFORM THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES, A) MONITOR FLOW PATHS AND CHARACTERIZE SOIL CHARACTERISTICS TO EVALUATE INFILTRATION RATES; B) USING HIGHEST FLOW PATHWAYS, IDENTIFY CRITICAL SAMPLING LOCATIONS OF POLLUTANT TRANSPORT AND ASSESS HUMAN HEALTH RISK; AND C) CALIBRATE THE OPENHYDROQUAL MODEL BY INPUTTING FIELD MONITORING DATA.SUBRECIPIENT:SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA COASTAL WATER RESEARCH PROJECT ($275,539) WILL SERVE AS THE LEAD OF WATER QUALITY INVESTIGATION WILL CONDUCT A SURVEY OF BIORETENTION-TYPE BMP PRACTICES ACROSS LAC TO IDENTIFY AND CATALOG DESIGN AND MAINTENANCE CONDITIONS PREVENTING OR PROMOTING EFFECTIVE OPERATION OF THE BMP IN TERMS OF PHYSICAL ABILITY TO CAPTURE RUNOFF. CATHOLIC UNIVERSITY OF AMERICA ($235,450) WILL COMMIT INFRASTRUCTURE SUPPORT AND A VARIETY OF RESOURCES AND DR. ARASH MASSOUDIEH WILL SERVE AS THE MODELING LEAD FOR THE PROJECT. LAWRENCE BERKELEY NATIONAL LABORATORY ($1,074,011) WILL SERVE AS GEOPHYSICAL INVESTIGATION LEAD FOR THE PROJECT. 
OUTCOMES:THE DELIVERABLES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE A FREE AND OPEN-SOURCE MODELING TOOL FOR EVALUATION OF PERFORMANCE OF EAR BMPS, IN ADDITION TO ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS. ENGINEERS, PLANNERS, AND OTHER USERS WILL BE ABLE TO INPUT PARAMETERS OF THEIR SPECIFIC BMP SYSTEMS AND BE ABLE TO ASSESS THE LONG-TERM PERFORMANCE OF BMPS USED FOR EAR, INCLUDING IDENTIFYING ANY RISKS OF POLLUTANT HAZARD RISKS TO GROUNDWATER. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE WATER RESOURCE MANAGERS, COMMUNITIES DEPENDENT ON GROUNDWATER SUPPLY, LA COUNTY WATER USERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

project_title: Protecting Water Quality during Enhanced Aquifer Recharge
project_description:
DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A GEOCHEMICAL COMPATIBILITY FRAMEWORK FOR ENHANCED AQUIFER RECHARGE (EAR) SUITABILITY ASSESSMENTS THAT EVALUATES CONTAMINANT (METALS, SALTS, PESTICIDES) MOBILIZATION FROM SOURCE WATERS.ACTIVITIES:THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE 1) TO EVALUATE THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF EXCESS SURFACE WATER AND WASTEWATER DISCHARGE THAT IS AVAILABLE FOR RECHARGE, 2) TO ASSESS GEOCHEMICAL, SURFACE, AND HYDROGEOLOGIC CONDITIONS FOR RECHARGE SUITABILITY, 3) TO CALCULATE CONTAMINANT RISK SCORES BASED ON SPATIAL DATA, MODELING TOOLS, AND POTENTIAL SHIFTS IN GEOCHEMISTRY DURING ENHANCED RECHARGE, AND 4) TO DETERMINE REGIONAL SITE SUITABILITY FOR ENHANCED RECHARGE USING A COMBINATION OF SOURCE WATER AVAILABILITY, AQUIFER HYDROGEOLOGY, AND CONTAMINANT MOBILIZATION RISKS.


SUBRECIPIENT:UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, DAVIS ($316,845) WILL LEAD RESEARCH TASK 1: ASSESSMENT OF VARIOUS SOURCE WATERS, WHICH IS FOCUSED ON EVALUATING THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF EXCESS SURFACE WATER (STORMWATER, FLOODWATER) AND WASTEWATER DISCHARGES AVAILABLE FOR RECHARGE IN THE WATERSHEDS OVERLYING KEY REGIONAL AQUIFERS ACROSS THE UNITED STATES (US). DR. DAHLKE'S LAB WILL ALSO CONTRIBUTE TO RESEARCH TASK 2: ASSESSMENT OF AMBIENT AQUIFER CONDITIONS, WHICH FOCUSES ON ASSESSING AMBIENT GEOCHEMICAL CONDITIONS, RELEVANT SURFACE CONDITIONS (E.G., AGROCHEMICAL USE), AND HYDROGEOLOGIC SUITABILITY OF KEY REGIONAL AQUIFERS ACROSS THE US. UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS, AUSTIN'S ($309,000) DR. BRIDGET R. SCANLON WILL LEAD THE EVALUATION OF AMBIENT AQUIFER CONDITIONS FOR THE PROPOSAL. THIS WORK WILL LEVERAGE THE RESEARCH SHE PREVIOUSLY LED FOR THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) UNDER THE POWELL RESEARCH PROGRAM RELATING AQUIFER STATUS TO GRACE SATELLITE DATA FOCUSING ON SPATIOTEMPORAL VARIABILITY IN WATER STORAGE. GROUND WATER PROTECTION COUNCIL ($171,099) WILL BE TO MANAGE THE COMMUNICATIONS AND ENGAGEMENT PROCESSES IN THREE KEY AREAS. 1) PROVIDE GUIDANCE DOCUMENT AND DASHBOARD PUBLICATION ASSISTANCE. 2) PROVIDE THREE FACILITATED COMMUNICATION OPPORTUNITIES, VIA ONLINE SEMINAR AND/OR FACE-TO-FACE MEETINGS WITH THE TARGETED COMMUNITY, TO INTRODUCE PROJECT AND GATHER FEEDBACK ON DESIGN AND CONTENT, PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY TO ALLOW FOR FEEDBACK ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE DASHBOARD TOOL, AND PROVIDE FOR OPPORTUNITIES TO DISSEMINATE THE RESULTS OF THE RESEARCH AND COMMUNICATE AVAILABILITY AND USE OF THE DASHBOARD TOOL. 3) PROVIDE PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE GUIDANCE DOCUMENT, DASHBOARD TOOL, DATA, AND REFERENCE INFORMATION DEVELOPED FOR THIS PROJECT ONLINE VIA THE GWPC ASR-MAR WORKGROUP'S ONLINE LIBRARY.
OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE A FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT, FRAMEWORK GUIDANCE FOR ENHANCED AQUIFER RECHARGE OPERATIONS, AND AN INTERACTIVE WEB-BASED MAPPING TOOL FOR RECHARGE SUITABILITY SITES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE WATER REGULATING OFFICIALS, THE GENERAL PUBLIC, AND HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT.

project_title: Development of Innovative Monitoring and Analysis Strategies for Rural Enhanced Aquifer Recharge Structures
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT AIMS TO EVALUATE SEVERAL METHODS OF MODIFICATION OF RURAL BASINS TO ENHANCE RECHARGE WHILE MONITORING THE EFFICACY OF EACH APPROACH.ACTIVITIES:IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS AND THE SITE OWNER (CITY OF ADA, OK), THIS PROJECT WILL EMPLOY MICROBIOLOGICAL, GEOCHEMICAL, SEDIMENTOLOGICAL, GROUNDWATER GAS MONITORING, GEOPHYSICAL, AND GROUNDWATER MODELING TOOLS TO TEST THE EFFECTIVENESS AND IMPACTS OF RURAL EAR STRUCTURES TO DETERMINE IF THESE STRUCTURES CAN BE DEPLOYED AS PART OF RURAL LAND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES TO SAFELY INCREASE GROUNDWATER SUPPLIES IN FRACTURED AND KARSTIC AQUIFERS.SUBRECIPIENT:TEXAS STATE UNIVERSITY ($443,592) WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE GROUNDWATER MODEL AND GAS TRANSPORT DEVELOPMENT (TASK E), INCLUDING TRAVEL TO RESEARCH SITES AND PROJECT MEETINGS. EAST CENTRAL UNIVERSITY OKA INSTITUTE ($294,482) WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE COLLABORATION AND ENGAGEMENT PLAN, HOST THE STAKEHOLDER MEETINGS, AND MANAGE THE MARKETING AND EDUCATIONAL PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE A GUIDANCE DOCUMENT FOR THE SITING AND ASSESSMENT OF RURAL EAR AS WELL AS A LITERATURE REVIEW AND MONITORING TOOLS DEVELOPED TO MANAGE RECHARGE PULSES THROUGH FRACTURED AND KARSTIC AQUIFERS, AND GUIDANCE ON MONITORING BIOGEOCHEMICAL CHANGES. THE OUTCOMES INCLUDE PROVIDING LAND AND WATER MANAGERS THE ABILITY TO SAFELY AND ECONOMICALLY IMPLEMENT RURAL EAR. THE BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE RESIDENTS OF OKLAHOMA WHOSE WATER SUPPLY COMES FROM ARBUCKLE SIMPSON AQUIFER, LOCAL AND TRIBAL GOVERNMENT, INDUSTRIAL AND AGRICULTURAL USERS, THE AQUATIC ENVIRONMENT OF CONNECTED STREAMS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

project_description:
DESCRIPTION:THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A WEB-BASED DECISION SUPPORT TOOL TO GUIDE COMMUNITIES, AGENCIES, AND PRACTITIONERS IN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF EAR IN DEEP, CONFINED AQUIFERS.
ACTIVITIES:FOUR EXPERIMENTS ARE PROPOSED (COMBINED WITH MODEL DEVELOPMENT AND APPLICATION) TO ADDRESS MULTIPLE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES. EXPERIMENTS ARE DESIGNED TO REVEAL RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN THE OUTCOMES OF SEVERAL RISK FACTORS AND TO PROMOTE SYNERGIES IN THE RESEARCH FINDINGS. SUBRECIPIENT:OLD DOMINION UNIVERSITY ($356,731) WILL ACTIVELY PARTICIPATE IN DATA COLLECTION AND SAMPLE ANALYSIS CONDUCTED AT THE PARML LABORATORY AND ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR CONTRIBUTING TO PROJECT DELIVERABLES. ODU RESEARCHERS WILL PARTICIPATE IN REGULARLY SCHEDULED MEETINGS REMOTELY. OUTCOMES:THE WEB-BASED DECISION SUPPORT TOOL WILL BE DESIGNED TO ADVANCE BEST PRACTICES AND ASSIST USERS IN A CAREFUL EVALUATION OF RISK AND PERFORMANCE FACTORS TO ENSURE EAR PROJECTS ARE EFFECTIVE, SUSTAINABLE, AND PROTECTIVE OF GROUNDWATER RESOURCES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE WATER QUALITY MANAGERS AND RESIDENTS OF THE EAST COAST.

project_title: Next-Generation Landfill Monitoring: A Multi-Scale Approach to Measuring Emissions for Evaluating and Financing Interventions
organization: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE
project_description:
DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP AND DEMONSTRATE AN INTEGRATED MULTI-SCALE AND MULTI-SENSOR APPROACH THAT WILL ALLOW LANDFILLS TO MORE EFFECTIVELY MONITOR EMISSIONS AT LOWER COST AND BE USED TO QUANTIFY THE EMISSIONS IMPACT OF INTERVENTIONS.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL : 1) TEST THE HYPOTHESIS THAT CONTINUOUS AIR MONITORING OF MUNICIPAL SOLID WASTE LANDFILLS IS FEASIBLE AND COST-EFFECTIVE THROUGH AN INTEGRATED MULTI-SCALE APPROACH (E.G., COORDINATED OBSERVATIONS WITH MULTIPLE SENSORS DEPLOYED ON FLUX CHAMBERS, UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES (UAVS), AIRCRAFTS, AND SATELLITES); AND 2) EXPLORE HOW THIS APPROACH CAN ESTABLISH THE EFFICACY OF INTERVENTIONS AND CREATE FINANCIAL INCENTIVES TO REDUCE EMISSIONS BY SERVING AS THE BASIS FOR ROBUST LANDFILL EMISSIONS REDUCTION QUANTIFICATION PROTOCOLS.SUBRECIPIENT:CARBON MAPPER ($111,979) WILL COORDINATE SENSING USING SATELLITE-BASED APPROACH AND WORK WITH THE RESEARCH TEAM ON SENSING TECHNOLOGIES COMPARISON AND INTEGRATION.

PSE HEALTHY ENERGY ($68,000) WILL PERFORM HAZARDOUS AIR POLLUTANT (HAP) TESTING FROM GAS SAMPLES TO SUPPLEMENT FIELD SENSING.

GTI ENERGY ($55,000) WILL WORK WITH THE RESEARCH TEAM TO CREATE FORMAL AND EQUITABLE PROTOCOLS FOR METHANE EMISSIONS ESPECIALLY FOR DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES AND THE INFLUENCE ON METHANE MODEL PREDICTION RESULTS.

OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS. OTHER EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE A DATASET OF EMISSIONS AT TARGETED LANDFILL FACILITIES; PROTOCOLS FOR FIELD MEASUREMENTS, AS WELL AS MORE ROBUST OFFSET PROTOCOLS, THAT WILL ENABLE AND ENCOURAGE GREATER USE OF INTERVENTIONS TO REDUCE LANDFILL AIR EMISSIONS; AND A MULTI-SENSING, MULTI-TEMPORAL DATASET THAT WILL QUANTIFY THE IMPACT OF WEATHER/CLIMATE, LANDFILL CONDITIONS AND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE: 1) IMPROVED APPROACHES FOR MONITORING AND QUANTIFYING EMISSIONS OF METHANE AND OTHER GASSES FROM LANDFILLS; 2) INCREASED DATA TO INFORM THE DEVELOPMENT OF LANDFILL EMISSIONS MODELS AND EMISSIONS INVENTORIES; 3) REDUCTION OF METHANE AND HAPS EMISSIONS THROUGH MITIGATION STRATEGIES (E.G., DIVERSION AND COMPOSTING PROGRAMS) AND WASTE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES; 4) IMPROVED ABILITY TO QUANTIFY METHANE AND CO-POLLUTANTS; 5) BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF FACTORS THAT AFFECT LANDFILL EMISSIONS THAT WILL INFORM STRATEGIES TO REDUCE EMISSIONS; AND 6) MITIGATION OF HAPS AND METHANE EMISSIONS FROM LANDFILLS IN AND NEAR NEIGHBORING COMMUNITIES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE RESIDENTS AFFECTED BY HAZARDOUS AIR POLLUTANTS EMITTED FROM LANDFILLS BEING STUDIES IN YOLO COUNTY, CA, ALAMEDA COUNTY, CA, AND CITY OF MIDLAND, MI AS WELL THE GENERAL PUBLIC, HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT.

project_title: Analysis of Continuous Monitoring Data with Inverse Atmospheric Models to Improve Landfill Gas Emissions Data and Elucidate Drivers of Emissions
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEMONSTRATE AND STANDARDIZE EXISTING INVERSE MODELING AND SPATIAL MAPPING METHODS FOR IDENTIFYING HOTSPOTS OF METHANE AND OTHER HEALTH IMPACTING GASES RELEASED FROM LANDFILLS AND TO MONITOR AND QUANTIFY THESE EMISSIONS.ACTIVITIES:THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE: 1) DEPLOY HIGH-SENSITIVITY LASER-BASED SENSORS TO MEASURE METHANE AT STRATEGIC LOCATIONS FOR TWO FULL YEARS AT DOWNWIND LOCATIONS OF FOUR LANDFILLS IN THE UNITED STATES; 2) DEPLOY SENSORS TO MEASURE LANDFILL GAS RELEASES THAT IMPACT LOCAL AIR QUALITY, INCLUDING AMMONIA, HYDROGEN SULFIDE AND ODORS, FOR TWO FULL YEARS AT THE SAME SITES AS THE METHANE SENSORS; 3) COLLECT COMPLEMENTARY DATA ON CARBON DIOXIDE, AMMONIA, AND HYDROGEN SULFIDE WITH THE LASER-BASED METHANE SENSOR TO DEMONSTRATE THE APPLICATION OF THE METHODS TO OTHER LANDFILL GASES; 4) USE PARALLEL DRONE-BASED MAPPING METHODS TO MAP METHANE CONCENTRATIONS ABOVE AND AROUND LANDFILLS TO IDENTIFY HOT SPOTS AND IDENTIFY THE LOCATION OF FUGITIVE EMISSIONS; AND 5) APPLY THE MONITORING DATA IN AN INVERSE ATMOSPHERIC TRANSPORT MODEL TO QUANTIFY LANDFILL EMISSIONS AND FOR CALCULATING THE IMPACT FROM ENVIRONMENTAL VARIABLES AND LANDFILL OPERATIONS ON EMISSIONS.SUBRECIPIENT:ST. LOUIS UNIVERSITY ($199,701) WILL COMPLETE THE DRONE MEASUREMENTS AND THE METEOROLOGICAL ANALYSES THAT WILL BE USED IN THE PROJECT.  ST. LOUIS UNIVERSITY WILL ALSO CONDUCT THE INVERSE MODELING ANALYSIS, DATA ANALYSIS, AND THE PREPARATION OF REPORT, PUBLICATIONS AND PRESENTATIONS COVER THE PROJECT RESULTS AND FINDINGS.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS. THE ANTICIPATED OUTPUTS INCLUDE ADVANCEMENTS IN METHODS FOR MONITORING LANDFILL GAS EMISSIONS, ADVANCEMENTS IN DRONE-BASED APPROACHES FOR IDENTIFYING HOT SPOTS AND PROCESSES THAT LEAD TO HIGH EMISSIONS, AND IDENTIFICATION OF FACTORS THAT AFFECT LANDFILL EMISSIONS AND EFFECTIVENESS OF MITIGATION STRATEGIES TO REDUCE EMISSIONS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE RESIDENTS AFFECTED BY HAZARDOUS AIR POLLUTANTS EMITTED FROM LANDFILLS, THE GENERAL PUBLIC, AND HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT.

project_title: Evaluation and Control of Emissions from MSW Landfills: Direct Measurement and Modeling
project_description:
DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO EVALUATE THE ACCURACY OF NEW EMISSIONS ESTIMATION METHODOLOGIES FOR EMISSIONS OF METHANE AND HAZARDOUS AIR POLLUTANTS FROM LANDFILLS AND PROVIDE GUIDANCE ON THEIR USE WHEN CALCULATING ANNUAL EMISSIONS.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL: 1) DETERMINE HOW THE EDDY COVARIANCE METHOD AND TRACER CORRELATION METHOD CAN CAPTURE EFFECTS OF ATMOSPHERIC CONDITIONS AND LANDFILL COVER TYPE ON EMISSIONS; 2) USE ATMOSPHERIC MODELING TO ASSESS THE ACCURACY OF EXISTING AND EMERGING METHODS, INCLUDING FIXED-POINT, AUTOMATED DRONE, AND FLUX CURTAIN MEASUREMENTS FOR MEASURING LANDFILL METHANE EMISSIONS; 3) USE BAYESIAN INVERSION WITH WEATHER RESEARCH AND FORECASTING OUTPUT TO OBTAIN WHOLE-LANDFILL METHANE EMISSION ESTIMATES FROM SATELLITE DATA; 4) EVALUATE THE UTILITY OF AUTOMATED GAS WELL CONTROL TO REDUCE LANDFILL GAS EMISSIONS; AND 5) EXAMINE VARIABILITY IN LANDFILL EMISSIONS UNDER FUTURE CLIMATE CONDITIONS.SUBRECIPIENT:THE SUBAWARD TO UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA DAVIS WILL BE FOR $235,615. THEY WILL LEAD AND COORDINATE ALL YOLO COUNTY CENTRAL LANDFILL FIELD ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING COLLECTING PRIMARY AND SECONDARY DATA FROM GAS COLLECTION SAMPLING AND TESTING, STANDARD SURFACE EMISSION SAMPLING, PLACEMENT OF EDDY COVARIANCE TOWERS AND FIXED-POINT SENSORS, TRACER CORRELATION METHOD MEASUREMENTS, OPERATION OF REMOTE-CONTROLLED DRONES FOR AERIAL GAS MEASUREMENTS, AND OPERATION OF THE AUTOMATED LANDFILL GAS COLLECTION SYSTEM. 

THE SUBAWARD TO UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA BERKELY WILL BE FOR $510,075. THEY LEAD AND CONDUCT ALL ACTIVITIES RELATED TO ATMOSPHERIC DISPERSION MODELING, INCLUDING THE CONFIGURING AND RUNNING THE WEATHER AND RESEARCH FORECASTING (WRF) MODEL, EVALUATION OF MODEL OUTPUTS, AND ESTIMATING EMISSIONS UNCERTAINTY.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS. OTHER EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE DATASETS OF LANDFILL EMISSIONS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE IMPROVED ESTIMATES OF LANDFILL EMISSIONS AND EVALUATIONS OF THE UTILITY OF LANDFILL COVER DESIGN AND AUTOMATED CONTROL OF GAS COLLECTION TO REDUCE EMISSIONS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE RESIDENTS AFFECTED BY HAZARDOUS AIR POLLUTANTS EMITTED FROM LANDFILLS BEING STUDIES IN YOLO COUNTY, CA, AND TURKEY RUN, GA AS WELL THE GENERAL PUBLIC, WHO ARE AFFECTED BY METHANE'S CONTRIBUTION TO CLIMATE CHANGE.

project_title: Integrating Measurements Across Platforms to Feasibly Assess Emissions and Mitigation of Methane and VOCs from Landfills
organization: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE OVERARCHING GOAL IS TO ASSESS THE PERFORMANCE AND FEASIBILITY TRADEOFFS OF INTEGRATING MEASUREMENTS ACROSS MEASUREMENT PLATFORMS TO ASSESS EMISSIONS AND MITIGATION OF METHANE AND VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUNDS (VOCS) FROM LANDFILLS. ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL: 1) ASSESS THE UNCERTAINTY IN LANDFILL METHANE EMISSIONS AT A REPRESENTATIVE SET OF THREE LANDFILLS USING A COMBINATION OF GROUND-BASED, AIRCRAFT, AND SATELLITE TOOLS; 2) DEVELOP METHANE EMISSIONS DATA FOR THREE DIFFERENT LANDFILLS FROM INTERANNUAL DOWN TO AN HOURLY TEMPORAL RESOLUTION, AND USE IT TO IMPROVE METHANE EMISSIONS MODELS; 3) DEVELOP A LANDFILL VOC EMISSIONS DATA SET THAT CAN BE USED TO ESTIMATE SPECIATED EMISSIONS BASED ON WASTE AND ENVIRONMENTAL PARAMETERS; 4) ASSESS INEXPENSIVE GROUND-BASED SYSTEMS TO ROUTINELY MONITOR VOCS; AND 5) ASSESS THE ABILITY OF VARIOUS MEASUREMENT SYSTEMS TO OBSERVE THE PERFORMANCE OF REAL-WORLD EMISSIONS MITIGATIONS. SUBRECIPIENT:THE SUBAWARD TO FORT LEWIS WILL BE FOR $50,000. THEY WILL BE INVOLVED IN THE DESIGN, FABRICATION, AND APPLICATION OF DYNAMIC FLUX CHAMBERS FOR USE IN MEASUREMENT LANDFILL GAS FLUXES.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS. OTHER EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE DATASETS OF TEMPORALLY AND SPATIALLY RESOLVED METHANE AND VOC SPECIES CONCENTRATIONS SPANNING 0.5-1.5 YEARS FOR THREE LANDFILLS AS WELL DATASETS OF METHANE AND VOC SPECIES EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE ADVANCEMENTS IN APPROACHES OF QUANTIFYING LANDFILL EMISSIONS AND IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF FACTORS THAT AFFECT EMISSIONS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE RESIDENTS AFFECTED BY HAZARDOUS AIR POLLUTANTS EMITTED FROM LANDFILLS TO BE STUDIES AS WELL THE GENERAL PUBLIC, WHO ARE AFFECTED BY METHANE'S CONTRIBUTION TO CLIMATE CHANGE.

project_title: Integrating Multi-Source Data for Landfill Methane Emission Quantification
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE USE OF LOW-COST SENSORS AND AMBIENT AIR MONITORING TO BETTER QUANTIFY SPATIOTEMPORAL VARIATIONS OF LANDFILL METHANE EMISSIONS.ACTIVITIES:THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE: 1) DEVELOP LOW-COST AIR QUALITY SENSORS TO CAPTURE METHANE VARIATION SPATIALLY AND TEMPORALLY; 2) INTEGRATE SENSOR DATA FROM FIXED LOCATIONS, MOBILE SAMPLING, AND DRONE SURVEYS TO MAP POLLUTION DISTRIBUTION AND ESTIMATE EMISSION FLUXES; AND 3) CORRELATE THE SPATIOTEMPORALLY RESOLVED METHANE EMISSION DATA WITH MULTIPLE ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS FOR EVALUATING METHANE REDUCTION TECHNIQUES.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS. THE ANTICIPATED OUTPUTS INCLUDE INTEGRATING SAMPLING TECHNOLOGIES FOR METHANE EMISSION QUANTIFICATION. THE DATASETS WILL INFORM LANDFILL OPERATIONS, METHANE EMISSION MODELS AND METHANE REDUCTION TECHNIQUES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE COMMUNITIES AFFECTED BY AIR POLLUTANTS EMITTED BY THE LANDFILL STUDY SITES IN IN MIAMI, FLORIDA AS WELL THE GENERAL PUBLIC, WHO ARE AFFECTED BY METHANE'S CONTRIBUTION TO CLIMATE CHANGE.

project_title: Children’s Environmental Health Center in U.S. Southern Great Plains
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A CENTER TO CHARACTERIZE THE ENVIRONMENTAL STRESSORS THAT AFFECT CHILDREN'S SCHOOL ABSENTEEISM AND EVALUATE NEW INTERVENTION METHODS.ACTIVITIES:THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO ASSESS CHILDREN'S HEALTH IMPACTS OF EARLY LIFE STAGE STRESSOR EXPOSURE AND TO INTRODUCE AFFORDABLE INTERVENTIONAL METHODS TO REDUCE HEALTH EFFECTS RELATING TO ENVIRONMENTAL CHEMICAL AND NON CHEMICAL STRESSORS. 1) THE ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS WHICH RELATE TO HEALTH ISSUES AND CAUSE SCHOOL ABSENTEEISM WILL BE IDENTIFIED AND CATEGORIZED. 2) INTERVENTION TECHNOLOGIES WILL ALSO BE COMPARED FOR EFFICIENCY IN MITIGATING CHILD HEALTH IMPACTS. 3) THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO ESTABLISH A DATA DRIVEN CHILDREN'S HEALTH AND SOCIAL VULNERABILITY INDEX TO GUIDE FUTURE DECISION MAKING AND ASSESS THE HEALTH DISPARITIES AND ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE OF RURAL SCHOOLS. SUBRECIPIENT:THE TOTAL COST FOR SUBAWARDS IS $1,223,932, WITH $552,166 TO UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS, $597,341 TO UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA - TULSA AND $74,425 TO UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA - NORMAN. THE UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS WILL LEAD RESEARCH TO CHARACTERIZE AND INTERVENE CHEMICAL AND NON-CHEMICAL STRESSORS TO REDUCE SCHOOL ABSENTEEISM CAUSED BY GASTROINTESTINAL AND RESPIRATORY DISEASES USING MIXED METHODS. THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA -TULSA WILL BE LEADING THE TRANSLATION CORE. OU NORMAN WILL DEVELOP  MICROCLIMATIC DATA COLLECTION AND DETERMINE SOCIOECONOMIC FACTORSOUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS DOCUMENTING THE CHARACTERIZATION AND EVALUATION OF THE CHEMICAL AND NON CHEMICAL STRESSORS THAT AFFECT SCHOOL ABSENTEEISM AND THE EFFECTIVENESS OF INDIVIDUAL AND COMBINED INTERVENTION METHODS. DATA WILL ALSO BE COLLECTED TO PRODUCE A PUBLIC CHILD HEALTH VULNERABILITY INDEX TO PREDICT THE SCHOOL ABSENTEEISM CAUSED BY GASTROINTESTINAL AND RESPIRATORY DISEASES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE RURAL AGRICULTURAL COMMUNITIES, STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

project_title: Integrating and Informing Actionable Agricultural Community Tools (II-ACT): Using Risk-Based Approaches for Evaluating Cumulative Early Life Environmental Stressors
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP AN EXPOSOME BASED APPROACH THAT CHARACTERIZES CHEMICAL AND NON-CHEMICAL STRESSORS TO PROVIDE DATA ON EARLY LIFE STAGE VULNERABILITIES IN AGRICULTURAL COMMUNITIES.ACTIVITIES:THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE THE 1) ASSESSMENT OF PESTICIDE DATA TO CHARACTERIZE CHILD EXPOSURE, GENETIC POLYMORPHISMS, HAZARD VALUES, 2) INTEGRATION OF COHORT BIOMARKERS INTO THE EXPOSOME BASED FRAMEWORK, 3) IDENTIFICATION OF CUMULATIVE EXPOSURE IMPACTS IN CHILDREN, AND 4) QUANTIFIED COMPARISONS OF BOTH NATIONWIDE AND STATE-SPECIFIC ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE MAPPING TOOLS.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE A DEVELOPMENTAL CENTER BASED ON EARLY LIFE-STAGE HEALTH STRESSORS AND NEW SCIENTIFIC UNDERSTANDINGS OF THE EFFECTS OF EXPOSURE TO CHEMICAL AND NON-CHEMICAL STRESSORS THROUGH AN EXPOSOME BASED APPROACH. DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS DOCUMENTING THE CHILDREN'S AGRICULTURAL COHORT INTEGRATIVE BIOMARKER ASSAYS IN RESPONSE TO ENVIRONMENTAL STRESSORS, CHARACTERIZATION OF COHORT EXPOSOME, DETAILED STATE AND REGION-SPECIFIC MAPS COMPARING MAPPING TOOLS, AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR IMPROVED FUTURE CUMULATIVE IMPACT MAPPING FRAMEWORKS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE RURAL AND AGRICULTURAL COMMUNITIES, FARM WORKERS, STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

project_title: The Bioecological Center for Rural Children’s Health (BeRCH)
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A TRANSDISCIPLINARY APPROACH TO EVALUATE AND MITIGATE THE CUMULATIVE HEALTH CONSEQUENCES OF CHEMICAL AND PSYCHOSOCIAL STRESSORS TO CHILDREN'S HEALTH THROUGH A COMMUNITY DRIVEN PARTICIPATORY FRAMEWORK. ACTIVITIES:THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO ASSES THE IMPACTS OF EARLY LIFE STAGE HEALTH STRESSORS AND CREATE NEW MODELS AND LANGUAGE TO ENCOMPASS THE DATA DRIVEN INSIGHTS. THIS PROJECT WILL 1) DOCUMENT AND EVALUATE THE CUMULATIVE IMPACT OF CHILDREN'S LOW-DOSE CHRONIC PESTICIDE EXPOSURE; 2) COMPARE EARLY-LIFE MICROBIOME WITH ENVIRONMENTAL STRESSOR EXPOSURES; AND 3) DEVELOP A STATEWIDE, CUMULATIVE IMPACT ASSESSMENT TO MITIGATE CHEMICAL AND NON CHEMICAL STRESSOR EXPOSURE.SUBRECIPIENT:THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE FARMWORKER ASSOCIATION OF FLORIDA (FWAW) WITH A SUBAWARD ($116,649) TO SERVE THE TRANSLATION CORE WITH COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND PUBLIC HEALTH OUTREACH TO THE FARMWORKER POPULATION IN IMMOKALEE, FLORIDA.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS DETAILING THE CORRELATIONS BETWEEN ENVIRONMENTAL STRESSORS AND CHILDHOOD DEVELOPMENT, EVALUATIONS OF MICROBIOME EFFECTS, AND A PUBLIC HEALTH CUMULATIVE IMPACT ASSESSMENT. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE AGRICULTURAL COMMUNITIES, FARM WORKERS, AND STATE AND LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH OFFICIALS

project_title: Work on Aquatic Toxicology and Ecology Research (CTP-WATER)
organization: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO BOLSTER THE PIPELINE OF ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS WHO ARE DEDICATED TO CHEMICAL RISK MANAGEMENT AND WATER QUALITY PROTECTION BY PROVIDING AUTHENTIC TRAINEE RESEARCH EXPERIENCES WITH EPA SCIENTISTS IN CONJUNCTION WITH UNIVERSITY FACULTY AND THEIR GRADUATE PROGRAMS AND RESOURCES.ACTIVITIES:THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVE IS TO PROVIDE UNIQUE CO-MENTORED RESEARCH EXPERIENCES TO FIFTEEN UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS, EIGHT M.S. STUDENTS, THREE PH.D. STUDENTS, AND FOUR POSTDOCTORAL INVESTIGATORS OVER FIVE YEARS. THIS EXPERIENCE WILL ADVANCE TRAINEE CAREERS INCREASING THE NUMBER AND PREPAREDNESS OF ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS ENTERING THE WORKFORCE.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS. ADDITIONAL OUTPUTS INCLUDE SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL PUBLICATIONS. ADDITIONALLY, PROJECT REPORTS, THESES, AND DISSERTATIONS WILL BE PRODUCED THAT FULFILL THE REQUIREMENTS FOR UNDERGRADUATE AND ADVANCED DEGREES. EXCEPTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE INCREASING IN THE NUMBER AND DIVERSITY OF ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS WHO CAN PRODUCTIVELY CONTRIBUTE TO UNDERSTANDING AND MANAGING ENVIRONMENTAL RISKS PARTICULARLY IN RELATION TO AQUATIC TOXICOLOGY AND ECOLOGY. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE THE TRAINEES (PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS) AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC BY GROWING THE ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTIST WORKFORCE.

project_title: Production of Lithium Carbonate from Geothermal Brine by Selective Extraction of Lithium Using a Novel Ion Sieve Method
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DESIGN AND DEVELOP A NOVEL METHOD TO EFFICIENTLY EXTRACT LITHIUM FROM A GEOTHERMAL BRINE WITH MINIMAL WATER LOSS.ACTIVITIES:SPECIFICALLY, RESEARCHERS PROPOSE TO DEVELOP A NOVEL ZIRCONIUM-DOPED COMPOUND THAT AS THE POTENTIAL TO INCREASE THE ADSORPTION CAPACITY OF LITHIUM FROM BRINE. THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES ARE TO: 1) SYNTHESIZE AND CHARACTERIZE THE LITHIUM-ION SIEVE (LI4MN4.9ZR0.1O12); 2) CONVERT THE LITHIUM ION TO THE MANGANESE ION WHICH IS THE ADSORBENT MATERIAL FOR THE LITHIUM EXTRACTION AND CONDUCT ADSORPTION-DESORPTION PROCESS; AND 3) PURIFY THE SALT PRECIPITATES TO PRODUCE LITHIUM CARBONATE.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS, AS WELL AS JOURNAL ARTICLES ON EFFORTS TO SYNTHESIZE THE NOVEL ZIRCONIUM COMPOUND AND INVESTIGATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF USING AS AN ADSORBENT FOR THE PROCESS OF LITHIUM EXTRACTION. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE LITHIUM MINING AND BATTERY INDUSTRIES, ELECTRIC VEHICLE MANUFACTURERS, WATER QUALITY MANAGERS, AND COMMUNITIES CURRENTLY AFFECTED BY LITHIUM MINING POLLUTION.

project_title: Environmental Monitoring and Remediation Technology Assessment Initiative (EMRTAI)
project_description:
DESCRIPTION:EPA IS SOLICITING APPLICATIONS FROM QUALIFIED (NON-PROFIT) ENTITIES THAT HAVE AN INTEREST AND EXPERIENCE IN CONDUCTING ASSESSMENTS OR TESTS OF NEW OR EXISTING ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING AND REMEDIATION TECHNOLOGIES FOR IDENTIFYING AND RECOVERING CRITICAL MINERALS (CMS) AT CONTAMINATED LEGACY MINING SITES. APPLICANTS MUST HAVE THE ABILITY AND KNOWLEDGE TO CONDUCT ASSESSMENT, TESTING AND QUALITY ASSURANCE SUPPORT FOR NEW (SBIR PHASE 2 AND 3) AND COMMERCIAL ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING AND REMEDIATION TECHNOLOGIES. ABILITY AND KNOWLEDGE CAN BE ILLUSTRATED IN A NUMBER OF WAYS, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO HAVING CONDUCTED THE SAME OR SIMILAR ACTIVITIES IN THE PAST AS THOSE DESCRIBED HERE. FAMILIARITY WITH FEDERAL COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT OR GRANT OPERATION AND MANAGEMENT WOULD ALSO BE HELPFUL FOR APPLICANTS TO HIGHLIGHT. DISPLAYING AND DESCRIBING PRODUCTIVITY UNDER THESE OR OTHER FEDERAL AGREEMENTS WOULD ALSO BENEFIT IN THE SOLICITATION PROCESS.ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE RECIPIENT MUST INCLUDE:

- ESTABLISHING A STAKEHOLDER GROUP AND TECHNICAL PANELS TO HELP IN PRIORITIZING TECHNICAL MONITORING AND RECOVERY NEEDS (I.E., CATEGORIES OF TECHNOLOGY TO ASSESS AND/OR TEST).

- DEVELOPING AND SUBMITTING A SCIENTIFIC DATA MANAGEMENT PLAN (SDMP, SEE SECTION I.F. AND IV.D.6) AND A POST-AWARD INITIATIVE QUALITY MANAGEMENT PLAN (QMP) AND OPERATING THE INITIATIVE IN ACCORDANCE WITH THEIR QMP.

- PROVIDING OUTREACH WORKSHOPS;

- PREPARING AND DEVELOPING TECHNOLOGY TESTING PROTOCOLS THAT INCLUDE STAKEHOLDER NEEDS.

- DEVELOPING PERFORMANCE METRICS FOR ASSESSING AND TESTING NEW OR EXISTING TECHNOLOGIES AS WELL AS SUSTAINABILITY METRICS FOR EVALUATING LONG TERM AND CROSS MEDIA IMPACTS OF THE CHARACTERIZATION OR RECOVERY TECHNOLOGIES.

- POTENTIALLY MANAGING SUBAWARDS/CONTRACTS (AS NEEDED) WITH ORGANIZATIONS FOR MANAGING ASSESSMENT, TESTING AND DATA COLLECTION, AND WRITE PROGRESS AND SUMMARY REPORTS.

RECIPIENT MAY CONDUCT (BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO) CM IDENTIFICATION/MONITORING AND RECOVERY PROJECTS THAT PROVIDE:

- OUTREACH ON THE INITIATIVE'S ACTIVITIES AND TRACK OUTCOMES FOR IMPACTS;

- TECHNOLOGY AND PROCESS EVALUATIONS OR DEMONSTRATIONS;

- TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, OUTREACH AND/OR TRAINING TO MODEL OR ACCELERATE SOLUTIONS;

- FEASIBILITY STUDIES;

- EXPANDING ACCEPTANCE OF MONITORING OR RECLAMATION TECHNOLOGIES AT MINING SITES THROUGH TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS OR TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE; OR

- DEMONSTRATION, TRAINING, OR TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROJECTS FOR DEVELOPING OR IMPROVING EXISTING TECHNOLOGIES FOR 'ALTERNATIVE USE.'

- HELP MAKE TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENTS MORE RELEVANT TO STAKEHOLDERS THROUGH SUCH ACTIVITIES AS ESTABLISHING RELATIONSHIPS WITH OTHER ORGANIZATIONS THAT CONDUCT TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT AND PERFORMANCE TESTING SIMILAR TO THAT UNDERTAKEN BY THE INITIATIVE.

TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS MUST INVOLVE NEW OR EXPERIMENTAL TECHNOLOGIES, METHODS, OR APPROACHES, WHERE THE RESULTS OF THE PROJECT WILL BE DISSEMINATED SO THAT OTHERS CAN BENEFIT FROM THE KNOWLEDGE GAINED IN THE DEMONSTRATION PROJECT. A PROJECT THAT IS ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH THE PERFORMANCE OF ROUTINE, TRADITIONAL, OR ESTABLISHED PRACTICES, OR A PROJECT THAT IS SIMPLY INTENDED TO CARRY OUT A TASK RATHER THAN TRANSFER INFORMATION OR ADVANCE THE STATE OF KNOWLEDGE, HOWEVER WORTHWHILE THE PROJECT MIGHT BE, IS NOT A DEMONSTRATION. THESE ACTIVITIES RELATE GENERALLY TO THE GATHERING OR TRANSFERRING OF INFORMATION OR ADVANCING THE STATE OF KNOWLEDGE. RECIPIENT SHOULD EMPHASIZE THIS 'LEARNING' CONCEPT, AS OPPOSED TO 'FIXING' AN ENVIRONMENTAL PROBLEM VIA A WELL-ESTABLISHED METHOD.

TO THE EXTENT PRACTICABLE, RECIPIENT'S WORK MUST EMBODY INNOVATION. INNOVATION FOR THE PURPOSES OF THIS RFA IS DEFINED AS THE PROCESS OF MAKING CHANGES; A NEW METHOD, CUSTOM OR DEVICE. INNOVATION CAN TAKE THE FORM OF WHOLLY NEW APPLI

project_title: Sensor on Wheels (SOW): A Field-Deployable Environmental Pathogen Detection Tool
organization: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A FIELD-DEPLOYABLE, RAPID, SENSITIVE, AND AFFORDABLE SENSOR ON WHEELS (SOW) DEVICE, WHICH WILL BE CAPABLE OF DETECTING MULTIPLE BACTERIA TARGETS.ACTIVITIES:THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO: 1) DESIGN AND SET UP THE SOW SYSTEM WITH A PORTABLE RAMAN SPECTROMETER AND MICROFLUIDIC CHIP, 2) VALIDATE THE PERFORMANCE WITH BACTERIA STANDARDS AND SPIKED ENVIRONMENTAL SAMPLES, 3) OPTIMIZE THE PERFORMANCE FOR LOCAL FIELD-TESTING, AND 4) FIELD-TEST THE SOW SYSTEM IN FLORIDA AND LOUISIANA BEFORE AND AFTER FLOODING/HURRICANES.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT IS THE DEVELOPMENT AN AFFORDABLE, SENSITIVE, RAPID, AND FIELD-DEPLOYABLE SYSTEM FOR DETECTING VIABLE BACTERIAL PATHOGENS AND INDICATOR BACTERIA IN VARIOUS FIELD SETTINGS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE POPULATIONS IN FLOOD/HURRICANE-PRONE REGIONS, HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

project_title: 2D MoS2-Based Field Effect Transistor Sensors for Airborne PFAS Detection
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A NOVEL DESIGN FOR ELECTRONIC SENSORS THAT DETECT AIRBORNE PER-/POLY-FLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS).ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT'S ACTIVITIES INCLUDE (1) ASSESSING THE SCALABILITY OF SENSOR FABRICATION; (2) EVALUATING THE PERFORMANCE AND ACCURACY OF PFAS DETECTION AND QUANTIFICATION IN DEVELOPED AIR SENSOR; AND (3) DEMONSTRATING THE OPERATION OF PFAS AIR SENSORS IN APPLICATION VIA DEPLOYMENT IN EXISTING AIR QUALITY STATIONS.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE PUBLICATIONS, DEMONSTRATIONS, AND ANNUAL PROGRESS REPORTS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE AN INNOVATIVE AND SCALABLE AIR SENSOR TECHNOLOGY FOR THE PURPOSE OF AIRBORNE PFAS DETECTION AND NEW INSIGHTS INTO NANOTECHNOLOGY-ENABLED SMART SENSORS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL AIR MONITORING REGULATORS, MANUFACTURING FACILITIES, AND COMMUNITIES AFFECTED BY AIRBORNE PFAS POLLUTION.

project_title: Understanding and Predicting Disparities in Organic Contaminant Levels in Blood Among the U.S. Population
organization: BOARD OF REGENTS OF NEVADA SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION
project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE AND UTILIZE PROTEX, AN ADVANCED COMPUTATIONAL MODEL, TO INVESTIGATE THE VARIATIONS IN BLOOD CHEMICAL CONCENTRATIONS AMONG INDIVIDUALS AND ANY DISPARITIES AMONG DIFFERENT SEXES AND RACIAL/ETHNIC GROUPS. THE TEAM WILL COLLECT DATA FROM PAST NHANES - NATIONAL HEALTH AND NUTRITION EXAMINATION SURVEY - TO PREDICT INTERINDIVIDUAL VARIABILITY IN BLOOD CONCENTRATIONS OF CHEMICAL CONTAMINANTS BASED ON INDIVIDUAL-SPECIFIC DIETS, PHYSIOLOGICAL FACTORS, AND ANTHROPOMETRICS ACROSS AMERICANS.ACTIVITIES:RESEARCH AIMS: 1) UPGRADE THE EXPOSURE AND TOXICOKINETIC MODEL, PROTEX, IN ORDER TO CALCULATE CHEMICAL BLOOD CONCENTRATIONS WITH THE ABILITY TO CONSIDER INTER-INDIVIDUAL VARIABILITY IN THE GUT METABOLISM RATE OF CHEMICALS; 2) DEVELOP DATABASES OF DEMOGRAPHICS, PHYSIOLOGY, ANTHROPOMETRICS, AND DIET COMPOSITION FOR NHANES PARTICIPATION, AND 3) ESTIMATE THE VARIATIONS IN BLOOD CONCENTRATION OF THREE CASE-STUDY PHTHALIC ACIDIC ESTERS TO EXAMINE DISPARITIES BETWEEN SEXES AND RACES/ETHNICITIES.  SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS ON THEIR EFFORTS TO USE THE PROTEX MODEL TO UNDERSTAND THE VARIATIONS OF THE BLOOD CONCENTRATIONS OF CHEMICAL CONTAMINANTS AMONG THE U.S. POPULATION AND TO PREDICT SUCH DISPARITIES BETWEEN SUBGROUPS OF THE POPULATION. THIS PROJECT IS IMPORTANT BECAUSE IT WILL PROVIDE DATA TO INFORM HOW SPECIFIC CHEMICALS IMPACT DIFFERENT POPULATIONS, THEREBY ADDRESSING CHEMICAL DISPARITIES TO IMPROVE HEALTH, ESPECIALLY IN DISADVANTAGED AND OVERBURDENED COMMUNITIES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE RISK ASSESSORS, REGULATORY ENTITIES, WATER QUALITY MANAGERS, CHEMICAL AND PHARMACEUTICAL COMPANIES, HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

project_description: DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP AN ANTIVIRAL REUSABLE FACE MASK CONCEPT FROM RECYCLED POLYSTYRENE AND DISCARDED SINGLE-USE FACE MASKS.ACTIVITIES:(1) THIS PROJECT WILL COLLECT AND CHARACTERIZE PLASTIC WASTE, (2) DEVELOP AND EVALUATE REUSABLE NANOFIBER FILTRATION SYSTEMS, AND (3) FABRICATE AND EVALUATE A 3D-PRINTED FACE MASK DESIGN.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE A NOVEL MULTI-USE FACE MASK CONCEPT THAT IS SIMILAR OR EXCEEDS N95 MASK PERFORMANCE AND NANOFIBER FILTRATION SCIENTIFIC DATA THROUGH PUBLICATIONS, REPORTS, AND CONFERENCES. THE OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE A NOVEL DESIGN OF A REUSABLE ANTIVIRAL FACE MASK THAT PROMOTES HUMAN HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE COMMUNITIES WITH POOR AIR QUALITY, STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.
